Demonym(s) [/wiki/Demonym]SheffielderTime zone [/wiki/Time_zone]Greenwich Mean Time [/wiki/Greenwich_Mean_Time] (UTC+0
[/wiki/UTC%2B0])PostcodeS [/wiki/S_postcode_area]Area code(s) [/wiki/Telephone_numbering_plan]0114 [/wiki/0114_(UK_dial_code)]
Websitewww.sheffield.gov.uk [http://www.sheffield.gov.uk]
Sheffield (/ˈʃɛfiːəld/ [/wiki/Help:IPA/English](About this sound
[//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/11px-Loudspeaker.svg.png] [/wiki/File:En-uk-Sheffield.ogg]
listen [//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/5/57/En-uk-Sheffield.ogg])) is a city [/wiki/City_status_in_the_United_Kingdom] 
and metropolitan borough [/wiki/Metropolitan_borough] in South Yorkshire [/wiki/South_Yorkshire], England [/wiki/England]. 
Historically [/wiki/Historic_counties_of_England] part of the West Riding of Yorkshire [/wiki/West_Riding_of_Yorkshire], its name
derives from the River Sheaf [/wiki/River_Sheaf], which runs through the city. With some of its southern suburbs annexed from 
Derbyshire [/wiki/Derbyshire], the city has grown from its largely industrial roots to encompass a wider economic base. The
population of the City of Sheffield is 575,400 (mid-2016 est.)[2] and it is one of the eight largest regional English cities that
make up the Core Cities Group [/wiki/Core_Cities_Group].[3] Sheffield is the third largest
[/wiki/List_of_English_districts_by_population] English district by population. The metropolitan population of Sheffield is
1,569,000.[1]

The city is in the eastern foothills of the Pennines [/wiki/Pennines], and the valleys of the River Don
[/wiki/River_Don,_Yorkshire] and its four tributaries, the Loxley [/wiki/River_Loxley], the Porter Brook [/wiki/Porter_Brook], the 
Rivelin [/wiki/River_Rivelin] and the Sheaf [/wiki/River_Sheaf]. 61% of Sheffield's entire area is green space, and a third of the
city lies within the Peak District [/wiki/Peak_District] national park [/wiki/National_park].[4] There are more than 250 parks,
woodlands and gardens in the city,[4] and Sheffield is estimated to contain over two million trees.[4]

In the 19th century, Sheffield gained an international reputation for steel [/wiki/Steel] production. Known as the Steel City
[/wiki/Steel_City], many innovations were developed locally, including crucible [/wiki/Crucible_steel] and stainless steel
[/wiki/Stainless_steel], fuelling an almost tenfold increase in the population in the Industrial Revolution
[/wiki/Industrial_Revolution]. Sheffield received its municipal charter [/wiki/Municipal_charter] in 1843, becoming the City of
Sheffield in 1893. International competition in iron and steel caused a decline in these industries in the 1970s and 1980s,
coinciding with the collapse of coal mining in the area.

The 21st century has seen extensive redevelopment [/wiki/Urban_renewal] in Sheffield along with other British cities. Sheffield's 
gross value added [/wiki/Gross_value_added] (GVA) has increased by 60% since 1997, standing at £9.2 billion in 2007. The economy
has experienced steady growth averaging around 5% annually, greater than that of the broader region of Yorkshire and the Humber
[/wiki/Yorkshire_and_the_Humber].[5]

The city has a long sporting heritage, and is home to the world's oldest football club, Sheffield F.C. [/wiki/Sheffield_F.C.][6] 
Games between the two professional clubs, Sheffield United [/wiki/Sheffield_United_F.C.] and Sheffield Wednesday
[/wiki/Sheffield_Wednesday_F.C.], are known as the Steel City derby [/wiki/Steel_City_derby]. The city is also home to the World
Snooker Championship [/wiki/World_Snooker_Championship].

HISTORY[EDIT [/W/INDEX.PHP?TITLE=SHEFFIELD&ACTION=EDIT&SECTION=1]]
Main article: History of Sheffield [/wiki/History_of_Sheffield]Lithograph drawing showing a large stately home in ruins
[//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b8/Ruins_of_Sheffield_Manor_1819_1.jpg/220px-Ruins_of_Sheffield_Manor_1819_1.jpg]
[/wiki/File:Ruins_of_Sheffield_Manor_1819_1.jpg] [/wiki/File:Ruins_of_Sheffield_Manor_1819_1.jpg]Sheffield Manor
[/wiki/Sheffield_Manor] ruins as they appeared c.1819The area now occupied by the City of Sheffield is believed to have been
inhabited since at least the late Upper Paleolithic [/wiki/Upper_Paleolithic], about 12,800 years ago.[7] The earliest evidence of
human occupation in the Sheffield area was found at Creswell Crags [/wiki/Creswell_Crags] to the east of the city. In the Iron Age
[/wiki/British_Iron_Age] the area became the southernmost territory of the Pennine [/wiki/Pennines] tribe called the Brigantes
[/wiki/Brigantes]. It is this tribe who are thought to have constructed several hill forts in and around Sheffield.[8]

Following the departure of the Romans, the Sheffield area may have been the southern part of the Brittonic [/wiki/Celtic_Britons] 
kingdom of Elmet [/wiki/Elmet], with the rivers Sheaf and Don forming part of the boundary between this kingdom and the kingdom of 
Mercia [/wiki/Mercia].[9] Gradually, Anglian [/wiki/Angles] settlers pushed west from the kingdom of Deira [/wiki/Deira]. A
Britonnic presence within the Sheffield area is evidenced by two settlements called Wales [/wiki/Wales,_South_Yorkshire] and
Waleswood close to Sheffield.[10] The settlements that grew and merged to form Sheffield, however, date from the second half of
the first millennium, and are of Anglo-Saxon [/wiki/Anglo-Saxons] and Danish [/wiki/Danelaw] origin.[8] In Anglo-Saxon times, the
Sheffield area straddled the border between the kingdoms of Mercia [/wiki/Mercia] and Northumbria [/wiki/Kingdom_of_Northumbria].
The Anglo-Saxon Chronicle [/wiki/Anglo-Saxon_Chronicle] reports that Eanred of Northumbria [/wiki/Eanred_of_Northumbria] submitted
to Egbert of Wessex [/wiki/Egbert_of_Wessex] at the hamlet of Dore [/wiki/Dore] (now a suburb of Sheffield) in 829,[11] a key
event in the unification of the kingdom of England under the House of Wessex [/wiki/House_of_Wessex].[12]

After the Norman conquest of England [/wiki/Norman_conquest_of_England], Sheffield Castle [/wiki/Sheffield_Castle] was built to
protect the local settlements, and a small town developed that is the nucleus of the modern city.[13] By 1296, a market had been
established at what is now known as Castle Square [/wiki/Castle_Square,_Sheffield],[14] and Sheffield subsequently grew into a
small market town [/wiki/Market_town]. In the 14th century, Sheffield was already noted for the production of knives [/wiki/Knife]
, as mentioned in Geoffrey Chaucer [/wiki/Geoffrey_Chaucer]'s The Canterbury Tales [/wiki/The_Canterbury_Tales],[15] and by the
early 1600s it had become the main centre of cutlery [/wiki/Cutlery] manufacture in England outside London, overseen by the 
Company of Cutlers in Hallamshire [/wiki/Company_of_Cutlers_in_Hallamshire].[16] From 1570 to 1584, Mary, Queen of Scots
[/wiki/Mary,_Queen_of_Scots], was imprisoned in Sheffield Castle and Sheffield Manor [/wiki/Sheffield_Manor].[17]

View across a partially wooded valley containing a reservoir
[//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/28/Dale_dike_reservoir.jpg/225px-Dale_dike_reservoir.jpg]
[/wiki/File:Dale_dike_reservoir.jpg] [/wiki/File:Dale_dike_reservoir.jpg]Dale Dike Reservoir [/wiki/Dale_Dike_Reservoir], the
original dam wall of this reservoir collapsed in 1864 causing the Great Sheffield Flood [/wiki/Great_Sheffield_Flood]During the
1740s, a form of the crucible steel [/wiki/Crucible_steel] process was discovered that allowed the manufacture of a better quality
of steel than had previously been possible.[18] In about the same period, a technique was developed for fusing a thin sheet of
silver onto a copper ingot to produce silver plating, which became widely known as Sheffield plate [/wiki/Sheffield_plate].[19] 
These innovations spurred Sheffield's growth as an industrial town,[20] but the loss of some important export markets led to a
recession in the late 18th and early 19th century. The resulting poor conditions culminated in a cholera [/wiki/Cholera] epidemic
that killed 402 people in 1832.[8] The population of the town grew rapidly throughout the 19th century; increasing from 60,095 in
1801 to 451,195 by 1901.[8] The Sheffield and Rotherham railway [/wiki/Sheffield_and_Rotherham_Railway] was constructed in 1838,
connecting the two towns. The town was incorporated as a borough [/wiki/Borough] in 1842 and was granted a city charter
[/wiki/City_status_in_the_United_Kingdom] in 1893.[21] The influx of people also led to demand for better water supplies, and a
number of new reservoirs were constructed on the outskirts of the town.

The collapse of the dam wall of one of these reservoirs in 1864 resulted in the Great Sheffield Flood
[/wiki/Great_Sheffield_Flood], which killed 270 people and devastated large parts of the town.[22] The growing population led to
the construction of many back-to-back dwellings that, along with severe pollution from the factories, inspired George Orwell
[/wiki/George_Orwell] in 1937 to write: "Sheffield, I suppose, could justly claim to be called the ugliest town in the Old World
[/wiki/Old_World]".[23]

A recession in the 1930s was halted by increasing international tensions as World War II [/wiki/World_War_II] loomed; Sheffield's
steel factories were set to work manufacturing weapons and ammunition for the war effort. As a result, the city became a target
for bombing raids, the heaviest of which occurred on the nights of 12 and 15 December 1940, now known as the Sheffield Blitz
[/wiki/Sheffield_Blitz]. More than 660 lives were lost and many buildings destroyed.[24]

Panorama of a brutalist housing estate [//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0e/Parkhill2.jpg/225px-Parkhill2.jpg]
[/wiki/File:Parkhill2.jpg] [/wiki/File:Parkhill2.jpg]Park Hill flats [/wiki/Park_Hill,_Sheffield], an example of 1950/60s council
housing estates in SheffieldIn the 1950s and 1960s, many of the city's slums were demolished, and replaced with housing schemes
such as the Park Hill flats [/wiki/Park_Hill,_Sheffield]. Large parts of the city centre were also cleared to make way for a new
system of roads.[8] Increased automation and competition from abroad resulted in the closure of many steel mills
[/wiki/Steel_crisis]. The 1980s saw the worst of this run-down of Sheffield's industries, along with those of many other areas of
the UK.[25] The building of the Meadowhall Centre [/wiki/Meadowhall_Centre] on the site of a former steelworks in 1990 was a mixed
blessing, creating much needed jobs but hastening the decline of the city centre. Attempts to regenerate the city were
kick-started when the city hosted the 1991 World Student Games [/wiki/Universiade], which saw the construction of new sporting
facilities such as the Sheffield Arena [/wiki/Sheffield_Arena], Don Valley Stadium [/wiki/Don_Valley_Stadium] and the Ponds Forge
[/wiki/Ponds_Forge] complex.[8]

Sheffield is changing rapidly as new projects regenerate some of the more run-down parts of the city. One such, the Heart of the
City Project, has initiated a number of public works in the city centre: the Peace Gardens [/wiki/Peace_Gardens] were renovated in
1998, the Millennium Galleries [/wiki/Millennium_Galleries] opened in April 2001, the Winter Gardens
[/wiki/Sheffield_Winter_Gardens] were opened in May 2003, and a public space to link these two areas, the Millennium Square
[/wiki/Millennium_Square_(Sheffield)], was opened in May 2006. Additional developments included the remodelling of Sheaf Square
[/wiki/Sheaf_Square], in front of the recently refurbished railway station. The new square contains "The Cutting Edge", a
sculpture designed by Si Applied Ltd[26] and made from Sheffield steel.

Sheffield was particularly hard hit during the 2007 United Kingdom floods [/wiki/2007_United_Kingdom_floods] and the 2010 'Big
Freeze' [/wiki/Winter_of_2009-2010_in_the_United_Kingdom]. Many landmark buildings such as Meadowhall and the Sheffield Wednesday
[/wiki/Sheffield_Wednesday] ground flooded due to being close to rivers that flow through the city. Since 2012, there have been
disputes between the city council and residents over the fate of the city's 36,000 highway trees, with 4,000 having been felled as
part of a scheme to maintain the city streets.[27] However, there have been plans for the highway maintenance to replant all
felled trees across the city, including those historically felled and not previously replanted.[28]

GOVERNMENT[EDIT [/W/INDEX.PHP?TITLE=SHEFFIELD&ACTION=EDIT&SECTION=2]]
See also: Sheffield local elections [/wiki/Sheffield_local_elections]View across a garden containing people enjoying a sunny day
towards a large Victorian building with a clock tower
[//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/PeaceGdnsSheffd.jpg/292px-PeaceGdnsSheffd.jpg]
[/wiki/File:PeaceGdnsSheffd.jpg] [/wiki/File:PeaceGdnsSheffd.jpg]Sheffield Town Hall [/wiki/Sheffield_Town_Hall], adjacent to the 
Peace Gardens [/wiki/Peace_Gardens], is an example of Victorian era [/wiki/Victorian_era] Gothic revival architecture
[/wiki/Gothic_revival_architecture].Sheffield is governed at the local level by Sheffield City Council [/wiki/Sheffield_City_Council]. It consists of 84 councillors
elected to represent 28wards [/wiki/Ward_(politics)]: three councillors per ward. Following the 2016 local elections, the
distribution of council seats is Labour [/wiki/Labour_Party_(UK)] 56, Liberal Democrats [/wiki/Liberal_Democrats_(UK)] 20, the 
Green Party [/wiki/Green_Party_of_England_and_Wales] 4 and UKIP [/wiki/United_Kingdom_Independence_Party] 4. The city also has a 
Lord Mayor [/wiki/Lord_Mayor_of_Sheffield]; though now simply a ceremonial position, in the past the office carried considerable
authority, with executive powers over the finances and affairs of the city council.

For much of its history the council was controlled by the Labour Party, and was noted for its leftist [/wiki/Left-wing_politics] 
sympathies; during the 1980s, when Sheffield City Council was led by David Blunkett [/wiki/David_Blunkett], the area gained the
epithet the "Socialist Republic of South Yorkshire [/wiki/People%27s_Republic_of_South_Yorkshire]".[29] However, the Liberal
Democrats controlled the Council between 1999 and 2001 and took control again from 2008 to 2011.

The majority of council-owned facilities are operated by independent charitable trusts. Sheffield International Venues
[/wiki/Sheffield_International_Venues] runs many of the city's sporting and leisure facilities, including Sheffield Arena
[/wiki/Sheffield_Arena] and the English Institute of Sport [/wiki/English_Institute_of_Sport_%E2%80%93_Sheffield]. Museums
Sheffield [/wiki/Sheffield_Galleries_and_Museums_Trust] and the Sheffield Industrial Museums Trust
[/wiki/Sheffield_Industrial_Museums_Trust] take care of galleries and museums owned by the council.[30][31]

The city returns five members of parliament to the House of Commons [/wiki/House_of_Commons_of_the_United_Kingdom], with a sixth,
the Member of Parliament for Penistone and Stocksbridge [/wiki/Penistone_and_Stocksbridge_(UK_Parliament_constituency)] 
representing parts of Sheffield and Barnsley.[32] The former Deputy Prime Minister Nick Clegg was an MP for Sheffield,
representing Sheffield Hallam [/wiki/Sheffield_Hallam_(UK_Parliament_constituency)].

GEOGRAPHY[EDIT [/W/INDEX.PHP?TITLE=SHEFFIELD&ACTION=EDIT&SECTION=3]]
Main article: Geography of Sheffield [/wiki/Geography_of_Sheffield]Sheffield is located at 53°23′N 1°28′W/53.383°N 1.467°W/ 53.383; -1.467
[//tools.wmflabs.org/geohack/geohack.php?pagename=Sheffield&params=53_23_N_1_28_W_type:city_region:GB]. It lies directly beside 
Rotherham [/wiki/Rotherham], from which it is separated largely by the M1 motorway [/wiki/M1_motorway]. Although Barnsley
Metropolitan Borough [/wiki/Metropolitan_Borough_of_Barnsley] also borders Sheffield to the north, the town itself is a few miles
further away. The southern and western borders of the city are shared with Derbyshire [/wiki/Derbyshire]; in the first half of the
20th century Sheffield extended its borders south into Derbyshire, annexing a number of villages,[33] including Totley
[/wiki/Totley], Dore [/wiki/Dore] and the area now known as Mosborough [/wiki/Mosborough] Townships. Directly to the west of the
city are the Peak District National Park [/wiki/Peak_District] and the Pennine [/wiki/Pennines] hill range, while the lowlands of
the South Yorkshire Coalfield [/wiki/South_Yorkshire_Coalfield] lie to the east.

Sheffield is a geographically diverse city.[34] The city nestles in the eastern foothills of the Pennines, and a natural
amphitheatre created by several hills[35] and the confluence of five rivers: Don [/wiki/River_Don,_South_Yorkshire], Sheaf
[/wiki/River_Sheaf], Rivelin [/wiki/River_Rivelin], Loxley [/wiki/River_Loxley] and Porter [/wiki/Porter_Brook]. As such, much of
the city is built on hillsides with views into the city centre or out to the countryside. Blake Street, in the S6 postcode area,
is the third steepest residential street in England, with a gradient of 16.6°.[36] The city's lowest point is just 29 metres (95
ft) above sea level near Blackburn Meadows [/wiki/Blackburn_Meadows], while some parts of the city are at over 500 metres (1,640
ft); the highest point being 548 metres (1,798 ft) at High Stones [/wiki/High_Stones], near Margery Hill [/wiki/Margery_Hill].
However, 79% of the housing in the city is between 100 and 200 metres (330 and 660 ft) above sea level.[37]

Estimated to contain over two million trees,[38] Sheffield has more trees per person than any other city in Europe, and according
to Sheffield City Council, it is England's greenest city,[39] a claim that was reinforced when it won the 2005 Entente Florale
[/wiki/Entente_Florale] competition. It has over 170 woodlands (covering 10.91 sq mi or 28.3 km2), 78 public parks (covering 7.07
sq mi or 18.3 km2) and 10 public gardens. Added to the 52.0 square miles (134.7 km2) of national park and 4.20 square miles (10.9
km2) of water this means that 61% of the city is greenspace [/wiki/Open_space_reserve]. Despite this, about 64% of Sheffield
householders live further than 300 metres (328 yd) from their nearest greenspace, although access is better in less affluent
neighbourhoods across the city.[4][40] Sheffield also has a very wide variety of habitat [/wiki/Habitat], comparing favourably
with any city in the United Kingdom: urban, parkland and woodland, agricultural and arable land, moors, meadows and
freshwater-based habitats. There are six areas within the city that are designated as sites of special scientific interest
[/wiki/List_of_Sites_of_Special_Scientific_Interest_in_South_Yorkshire].[41]

The present city boundaries were set in 1974 (with slight modification in 1994), when the former county borough
[/wiki/County_borough] of Sheffield merged with Stocksbridge [/wiki/Stocksbridge] Urban District
[/wiki/Urban_district_(Great_Britain_and_Ireland)] and two parishes from the Wortley Rural District [/wiki/Wortley_Rural_District]
.[4] This area includes a significant part of the countryside surrounding the main urban region. Roughly a third of Sheffield lies
in the Peak District National Park [/wiki/Peak_District]. No other English city has parts of a national park within its boundary,
[42] until the creation in March 2010 of the South Downs National Park [/wiki/South_Downs_National_Park], part of which lies
within Brighton and Hove [/wiki/Brighton_and_Hove].

Neighbouring towns and citiesHuddersfield [/wiki/Huddersfield], Penistone [/wiki/Penistone]Barnsley [/wiki/Barnsley], Leeds
[/wiki/Leeds], Wakefield [/wiki/Wakefield]Rotherham [/wiki/Rotherham], Doncaster [/wiki/Doncaster]Manchester [/wiki/Manchester], 
Glossop [/wiki/Glossop][//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/Pfeil_oben.svg/14px-Pfeil_oben.svg.png][//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/Pfeil_links.svg/17px-Pfeil_links.svg.png]
Sheffield[//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c5/Pfeil_rechts.svg/17px-Pfeil_rechts.svg.png][//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c3/Pfeil_unten.svg/14px-Pfeil_unten.svg.png]
Worksop [/wiki/Worksop], Retford [/wiki/Retford], Lincoln [/wiki/Lincoln,_England]Buxton [/wiki/Buxton], Bakewell [/wiki/Bakewell]
, Matlock [/wiki/Matlock,_Derbyshire]Chesterfield [/wiki/Chesterfield], Dronfield [/wiki/Dronfield], Derby [/wiki/Derby]Mansfield
[/wiki/Mansfield], Newark [/wiki/Newark-on-Trent], Nottingham [/wiki/Nottingham]CLIMATE[EDIT [/W/INDEX.PHP?TITLE=SHEFFIELD&ACTION=EDIT&SECTION=4]]
Like the rest of the United Kingdom, the climate in Sheffield is generally temperate [/wiki/Temperate]. The Pennines
[/wiki/Pennines] to the west of the city can create a cool, gloomy and wet environment, but they also provide shelter from the
prevailing westerly winds, casting a "rain shadow" across the area.[43] Between 1971 and 2000 Sheffield averaged 824.7 millimetres
(32.47 in) of rain per year; December was the wettest month with 91.9 millimetres (3.62 in) and July the driest with 51.0
millimetres (2.01 in). July was also the hottest month, with an average maximum temperature of 20.8 °C (69.4 °F). The average
minimum temperature in January and February was 1.6 °C (34.9 °F),[44] though the lowest temperatures recorded in these months can
be between −10 and −15 °C (14 and 5 °F), although since 1960, the temperature has never fallen below −9.2 °C (15.4 °F),[45] 
suggesting that urbanisation around the Weston Park site during the second half of the 20th century may prevent temperatures below
−10 °C (14 °F) occurring.

The coldest temperature to be recorded in recent years was −8.2 °C (17.2 °F).[46] (Note: The official Weston Park Weather Station
statistics, which can also be viewed at Sheffield Central Library [/wiki/Sheffield_Central_Library], has the temperature at −8.7
°C (16.3 °F), recorded on 20 December, and states that to be the lowest December temperature since 1981.) The coldest temperature
ever recorded in the city of Sheffield at Weston Park [/wiki/Weston_Park,_Sheffield], since records began in 1882, is −14.5 °C
(5.9 °F), registered in February 1895.[citation needed [/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed]] The lowest daytime maximum temperature
in the city since records began is −5.6 °C (21.9 °F), also recorded in February 1895.[citation needed
[/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed]] More recently, a −4.4 °C (24.1 °F) was recorded as a daytime maximum at Weston Park, on 20
December 2010.(from the Weston Park Weather Station statistics, which also can be viewed at Sheffield Central Library.) On
average, through the winter months of December to March, there are 67 days during which ground frost occurs.[43]
