[/wiki/Sunshine_duration]45.268.3111.9144.0190.9179.5199.5185.0136.290.753.740.01,444.9Source #1: Met Office [/wiki/Met_Office]
[44]Source #2: KNMI [/wiki/Royal_Netherlands_Meteorological_Institute][47][48]The Weston Park Weather station, established in
1882, is one of the longest running weather stations in the United Kingdom [/wiki/United_Kingdom]. It has recorded weather for
more than 125 years, and a 2008 report showed that the climate of Sheffield is warming faster than it has at any time during this
period, with 1990 and 2006 being the hottest years on record.[49] In collaboration with the Stockholm Environment Institute
[/wiki/Stockholm_Environment_Institute], Sheffield developed a carbon footprint [/wiki/Carbon_footprint] (based on 2004/05
consumption figures) of 5,798,361tonnes [/wiki/Tonnes] per year. This compares to the UK's total carbon footprint of 698,568,010
tonnes per year. The factors with the greatest impact are housing (34%), transport (25%), consumer (11%), private services (9%),
public services (8%), food (8%) and capital investment (5%).[50] Sheffield City Council has signed up to the 10:10 [/wiki/10:10] 
campaign.[51]

SUBDIVISIONS[EDIT [/W/INDEX.PHP?TITLE=SHEFFIELD&ACTION=EDIT&SECTION=5]]
Main article: Areas of Sheffield [/wiki/Areas_of_Sheffield]Sheffield is made up of many suburbs and neighbourhoods, many of which
developed from villages or hamlets [/wiki/Hamlet_(place)] that were absorbed into Sheffield as the city grew.[8] These historical
areas are largely ignored by the modern administrative and political divisions of the city; instead it is divided into 28
electoral wards [/wiki/Ward_(politics)], with each ward generally covering 4–6 areas.[52] These electoral wards are grouped into
six parliamentary constituencies [/wiki/United_Kingdom_constituencies]. Sheffield is largely unparished
[/wiki/Civil_parishes_in_England], but Bradfield [/wiki/Bradfield,_South_Yorkshire] and Ecclesfield [/wiki/Ecclesfield] have
parish councils, and Stocksbridge [/wiki/Stocksbridge] has a town council.[53]

SKYLINE[EDIT [/W/INDEX.PHP?TITLE=SHEFFIELD&ACTION=EDIT&SECTION=6]]
[//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c3/Sheffield_wide_from_Meersbrook_Park.jpg/1000px-Sheffield_wide_from_Meersbrook_Park.jpg]
[/wiki/File:Sheffield_wide_from_Meersbrook_Park.jpg] [/wiki/File:Sheffield_wide_from_Meersbrook_Park.jpg]Panorama of Sheffield
taken from Meersbrook Park [/wiki/Meersbrook_Park]DEMOGRAPHY[EDIT [/W/INDEX.PHP?TITLE=SHEFFIELD&ACTION=EDIT&SECTION=7]]
Main article: Demography of Sheffield [/wiki/Demography_of_Sheffield]Population ChangeYearPop.±%180160,095—182184,540+40.7%1841
134,599+59.2%1861219,634+63.2%1881335,953+53.0%1901451,195+34.3%1921543,336+20.4%1941569,884+4.9%1951577,050+1.3%1961574,915−0.4%
1971572,794−0.4%1981530,844−7.3%1991528,708−0.4%2001513,234−2.9%2007530,300+3.3%2011551,800+4.1%[54]The United Kingdom Census 2001 [/wiki/United_Kingdom_Census_2001] reported a resident population for Sheffield of 513,234, a 2%
decline from the 1991 census.[55] The city is part of the wider Sheffield urban area [/wiki/Sheffield_urban_area], which had a
population of 640,720.[56] In 2011 [/wiki/United_Kingdom_Census_2011] the racial composition of Sheffield's population was 84% 
White [/wiki/White_people] (81% White British [/wiki/White_British], 0.5% White Irish [/wiki/Irish_migration_to_Great_Britain],
0.1% Gypsy [/wiki/Gypsy_(term)] or Irish Traveller [/wiki/Irish_Traveller], 2.3% Other White [/wiki/Other_White]), 2.4% of mixed
race [/wiki/Mixed_(United_Kingdom_ethnicity_category)] (1.0% White and Black Caribbean, 0.2% White and Black African, 0.6% White
and Asian, 0.6% Other Mixed), 8% Asian [/wiki/British_Asian] (1.1% Indian [/wiki/British_Indian], 4% Pakistani
[/wiki/British_Pakistanis], 0.6% Bangladeshi [/wiki/British_Bangladeshi], 1.3% Chinese [/wiki/British_Chinese], 1.0% Other Asian),
3.6% Black [/wiki/Black_British] (2.1% African, 1% Caribbean [/wiki/British_African-Caribbean_people], 0.5% Other Black
[/wiki/Other_Black]), 1.5% Arab [/wiki/British_Arab] and 0.7% of other ethnic heritage.[57][not in citation given
[/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability]] In terms of religion, 53% of the population are Christian, 6% are Muslim, 0.6% are Hindu, 0.4%
are Buddhist, 0.2% are Sikh, 0.1% are Jewish, 0.4% belong to another religion, 31% have no religion and 7% did not state their
religion.[58] The largest quinary [/wiki/Quinary] group is 20- to 24-year-olds (9%) because of the large university student
population.[59]

The population of Sheffield peaked in 1951 at 577,050, and has since declined steadily. However, the mid-2007 population estimate
was 530,300, representing an increase of about 17,000 residents since 2001.[60]

Although a city, Sheffield is informally known as "the largest village in England [/wiki/Largest_village_in_England]",[61][62][63] 
because of a combination of topographical isolation and demographic stability.[61] It is relatively geographically isolated, being
cut off from other places by a ring of hills.[64][65] (Local folklore insists that, like Rome, Sheffield was built "on seven
hills".[65]) The land surrounding Sheffield was unsuitable for industrial use,[61] and now includes several protected green belt
[/wiki/Green_belt] areas.[66] These topographical factors have served to restrict urban spread,[66] resulting in a relatively
stable population size and a low degree of mobility.

ECONOMY[EDIT [/W/INDEX.PHP?TITLE=SHEFFIELD&ACTION=EDIT&SECTION=8]]
Main article: Economy of Sheffield [/wiki/Economy_of_Sheffield]See also: List of companies in Sheffield
[/wiki/List_of_companies_in_Sheffield]Labour profileTotal employee jobs255,700Full-time168,00065.7%Part-time87,70034.3%
Manufacturing31,80012.4%Construction8,5003.3%Services214,90084.1%Distribution, hotels & restaurants58,80023.0%Transport &
communications14,2005.5%Finance, IT, other business activities51,80020.2%Public admin, education & health77,50030.3%Other services
12,7005.0%Tourism-related18,4007.2%St Paul's Tower, a new, mixed use development which forms part of the St Paul's Place
development. In the top left corner is the Main St Paul's tower itself. Below it is the Tower 2, connected to the main tower but
half the height. To the right is another office building in the same development. All have been completed within the last 5 years
and represent some of the newest architecture in the city.
[//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/St_Pauls_Place_Sheffield.png/170px-St_Pauls_Place_Sheffield.png]
[/wiki/File:St_Pauls_Place_Sheffield.png] [/wiki/File:St_Pauls_Place_Sheffield.png]St Paul's Place [/wiki/St_Paul%27s_Place],
2010. St Paul's Tower [/wiki/St_Pauls_Tower], the tallest building in Sheffield, is in the centre.After many years of decline, the
Sheffield economy is going through a strong revival. The 2004 Barclays Bank [/wiki/Barclays_Bank] Financial Planning study[67] 
revealed that, in 2003, the Sheffield district of Hallam [/wiki/Sheffield_Hallam_(UK_Parliament_constituency)] was the highest
ranking area outside London for overall wealth, the proportion of people earning over £60,000 a year standing at almost 12%. A
survey by Knight Frank [/wiki/Knight_Frank][68] revealed that Sheffield was the fastest-growing city outside London for office and
residential space and rents during the second half of 2004. This can be seen by the current surge of redevelopments, including the 
City Lofts Tower [/wiki/St_Pauls_Tower] and accompanying St Paul's Place [/wiki/St_Paul%27s_Place], Velocity Living
[/wiki/Velocity_Living] and the Moor redevelopment,[69] the forthcoming NRQ [/wiki/New_Retail_Quarter] and the recently completed 
Winter Gardens [/wiki/Sheffield_Winter_Gardens], Peace Gardens [/wiki/Peace_Gardens], Millennium Galleries
[/wiki/Millennium_Galleries] and many projects under the Sheffield One [/wiki/Sheffield_One] redevelopment agency. The Sheffield
economy grew from £5.6 billion in 1997 (1997 GVA)[70] to £9.2 billion in 2007 (2007 GVA).[71]

The "UK Cities Monitor 2008" placed Sheffield among the top ten "best cities to locate a business today", the city occupying third
and fourth places respectively for best office location and best new call centre [/wiki/Call_centre] location. The same report
places Sheffield in third place regarding "greenest reputation" and second in terms of the availability of financial incentives.
[72]

The Bessemer Converter located at Kelham Island Museum. The converter is located within an old industrial facility typical of
those constructed during the Industrial Revolution.
[//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3a/Bessemer_5180.JPG/220px-Bessemer_5180.JPG] [/wiki/File:Bessemer_5180.JPG] 
[/wiki/File:Bessemer_5180.JPG]The Bessemer Converter at Kelham Island Museum.Sheffield has an international reputation for
metallurgy and steel-making.[73] Many innovations in these fields have been made in Sheffield, for example Benjamin Huntsman
[/wiki/Benjamin_Huntsman] discovered the crucible technique [/wiki/Crucible_technique] in the 1740s at his workshop in Handsworth
[/wiki/Handsworth,_South_Yorkshire].[74] This process was rendered obsolete in 1856 by Henry Bessemer [/wiki/Henry_Bessemer]'s
invention of the Bessemer converter [/wiki/Bessemer_converter]. Thomas Boulsover [/wiki/Thomas_Boulsover] invented Sheffield Plate
[/wiki/Sheffield_Plate] (silver-plated copper) in the early 18th century. Stainless steel [/wiki/Stainless_steel] was invented by 
Harry Brearley [/wiki/Harry_Brearley] in 1912,[75] and the work of F. B. Pickering [/wiki/Frederick_Brian_Pickering] and T.
Gladman throughout the 1960s, 1970s and 1980s was fundamental to the development of modern high-strength low-alloy steels.[76] 
Further innovations continue, with new advanced manufacturing technologies and techniques being developed on the Advanced
Manufacturing Park [/wiki/Advanced_Manufacturing_Park] by Sheffield's universities and other independent research organisations.
[77] Organisations located on the AMP include the Advanced Manufacturing Research Centre (AMRC, a research partnership between the 
Boeing Company [/wiki/Boeing_Company] and the University of Sheffield [/wiki/University_of_Sheffield]), Castings Technology
International (CTI), The Welding Institute [/wiki/The_Welding_Institute] (TWI),[78] and William Cook Group
[/wiki/William_Cook_Group].[79][80]

Forgemasters [/wiki/Sheffield_Forgemasters], founded in 1805, is the sole remaining independent steel works [/wiki/Steel_works] in
the world and dominates the north east of Sheffield around the Lower Don Valley [/wiki/Lower_Don_Valley].[81] The firm has a
global reputation for producing the largest and most complex steel forgings and castings and is certified to produce critical
nuclear components, with recent projects including the Royal Navy [/wiki/Royal_Navy]'s Astute-class [/wiki/Astute_class_submarine] 
submarines.[82] The firm also has the capacity for pouring the largest single ingot (570 tonnes) in Europe and is currently in the
process of expanding its capabilities.[83]

While iron and steel have long been the main industries of Sheffield, coal mining [/wiki/Coal_mining] has also been a major
industry, particularly in the outlying areas, and the Palace of Westminster [/wiki/Palace_of_Westminster] in London was built
using limestone [/wiki/Limestone] from quarries [/wiki/Quarry] in the nearby village of Anston [/wiki/Anston]. Other areas of
employment include call centres [/wiki/Call_centre], the City Council [/wiki/City_Council], universities and hospitals.

Fargate shopping precinct, Sheffield. Once a busy road, it has been pedestrianised for several decades and is Sheffield's main
City Centre shopping area, home to many well-known companies. The image shows classical architecture on both sides with one plan
spaces in the centre, dotted with trees and the buildings on the High Street are visible beyond the trees.
[//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/Fargate_sheffield_2.png/220px-Fargate_sheffield_2.png]
[/wiki/File:Fargate_sheffield_2.png] [/wiki/File:Fargate_sheffield_2.png]Fargate shopping areaSheffield is a major retail centre,
and is home to many High Street [/wiki/High_Street] and department stores [/wiki/Department_store] as well as designer boutiques.
[84] The main shopping areas in the city centre are on The Moor [/wiki/The_Moor_Quarter] precinct, Fargate [/wiki/Fargate], 
Orchard Square [/wiki/Orchard_Square] and the Devonshire Quarter [/wiki/Devonshire_Quarter]. Department stores in the city centre
include John Lewis [/wiki/John_Lewis_Partnership], Marks and Spencer [/wiki/Marks_and_Spencer], Atkinsons [/wiki/Atkinsons] and 
Debenhams [/wiki/Debenhams]. Sheffield's main market was once Castle Market [/wiki/Castle_Market], built above the remains of the
castle. This has since been demolished.[85] Sheffield Moor Market opened in 2013. Shopping areas outside the city centre include
the Meadowhall [/wiki/Meadowhall_Shopping_Centre] shopping centre and retail parks, Ecclesall Road [/wiki/Ecclesall_Road], London
Road [/wiki/London_Road_(Sheffield)], Hillsborough [/wiki/Hillsborough,_South_Yorkshire], Firth Park [/wiki/Firth_Park] and the 
Crystal Peaks [/wiki/Crystal_Peaks] shopping centre. In a 2010 survey of forecast expenditure at retail centres in the United
Kingdom, Meadowhall was ranked 12th and Sheffield City Centre [/wiki/Sheffield_City_Centre] 19th.[86]

Sheffield has a District Energy system that exploits the city's domestic waste, by incinerating [/wiki/Sheffield_Incinerator] it
and converting the energy from it to electricity. It also provides hot water, which is distributed through over 25 miles (40 km)
of pipes under the city, via two networks. These networks supply heat and hot water for many buildings throughout the city. These
include not only cinemas, hospitals, shops and offices, but also universities (Sheffield Hallam University
[/wiki/Sheffield_Hallam_University] and the University of Sheffield [/wiki/University_of_Sheffield]), and residential properties.
[87] Energy generated in a waste plant produces 60megawatts [/wiki/Megawatt] of thermal energy and up to 19megawatts
[/wiki/Megawatt] of electrical energy from 225,000tonnes [/wiki/Tonnes] of waste.[88]

In 2012, Sheffield City Region Enterprise Zone [/wiki/Sheffield_City_Region_Enterprise_Zone] was launched to promote development
in a number of sites in Sheffield and across the wider region. In March 2014 additional sites were added to the zone.[89]

TRANSPORT[EDIT [/W/INDEX.PHP?TITLE=SHEFFIELD&ACTION=EDIT&SECTION=9]]
Main article: Transport in Sheffield [/wiki/Transport_in_Sheffield]NATIONAL AND INTERNATIONAL TRAVEL[EDIT [/W/INDEX.PHP?TITLE=SHEFFIELD&ACTION=EDIT&SECTION=10]]
Night view across an open plaza dominated by a long curving water feature that is decoratively lit. At the far side of the plaza
there is the arched frontage of a railway station building
[//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/14/Sheffield_Station_from_Sheaf_Square.jpg/220px-Sheffield_Station_from_Sheaf_Square.jpg]
[/wiki/File:Sheffield_Station_from_Sheaf_Square.jpg] [/wiki/File:Sheffield_Station_from_Sheaf_Square.jpg]Sheffield railway station
[/wiki/Sheffield_railway_station]ROAD[EDIT [/W/INDEX.PHP?TITLE=SHEFFIELD&ACTION=EDIT&SECTION=11]]
Sheffield is linked into the national motorway network via the M1 [/wiki/M1_motorway] and M18 [/wiki/M18_motorway_(Great_Britain)] 
motorways.[90] The M1 skirts the north-east of the city, linking Sheffield with London to the south and Leeds [/wiki/Leeds] to the
north, and crosses Tinsley Viaduct [/wiki/Tinsley_Viaduct] near Rotherham; the M18 branches from the M1 close to Sheffield,
linking the city with Doncaster [/wiki/Doncaster], Doncaster Sheffield Airport [/wiki/Doncaster_Sheffield_Airport], and the Humber
[/wiki/Humber] ports. The Sheffield Parkway [/wiki/Sheffield_Parkway] connects the city centre with the motorways.

RAIL[EDIT [/W/INDEX.PHP?TITLE=SHEFFIELD&ACTION=EDIT&SECTION=12]]
Major railway routes through Sheffield railway station [/wiki/Sheffield_railway_station] include the Midland Main Line
[/wiki/Midland_Main_Line], which links the city to London via the East Midlands, the Cross Country Route
[/wiki/Cross_Country_Route] which links the East of Scotland and Northeast of England with the West Midlands
[/wiki/West_Midlands_(region)] and the Southwest, and the lines linking Liverpool and Manchester with Hull
[/wiki/Kingston_upon_Hull] and East Anglia [/wiki/East_Anglia].[91] With the redevelopment of London St Pancras station (now St
Pancras International [/wiki/St_Pancras_International]) complete, Sheffield has a direct connection to continental Europe
[/wiki/Continental_Europe]. East Midlands Trains [/wiki/East_Midlands_Trains] run services to St Pancras International and 
Eurostar [/wiki/Eurostar] run services from there to France and Belgium.[92] The Master Cutler [/wiki/Master_Cutler_(train)], a
named passenger express train running from Sheffield railway station to London St Pancras, provides a direct connection to the
capital.

High Speed 2 [/wiki/High_Speed_2] will serve a city centre station in Sheffield, to be operational by 2033 with services to
Birmingham, London, Leeds and Newcastle. There will be four trains an hour serving the station, with journey times to London and
Birmingham reduced to 1 hour 19 minutes and 48 minutes respectively.[93]

Other trains serving Sheffield (apart from East Midland Trains) are provided by CrossCountry [/wiki/CrossCountry], TransPennine
Express [/wiki/TransPennine_Express] and Northern [/wiki/Northern_(train_operating_company)]. Aside from the main railway station
there are five other stations in Sheffield. Meadowhall [/wiki/Meadowhall_Interchange], a bus, rail and tram interchange, is the
second largest station and accommodates a number of services including the long distance CrossCountry [/wiki/CrossCountry] 
service. Dore and Totley [/wiki/Dore_and_Totley_railway_station], Woodhouse [/wiki/Woodhouse_railway_station], Chapeltown
[/wiki/Chapeltown_railway_station] and Darnall [/wiki/Darnall_railway_station] stations serve as commuter stations
[/wiki/Commuter_rail_in_the_United_Kingdom] for suburban communities but are also connected to the national rail network
[/wiki/Rail_transport_in_Great_Britain].

[//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ea/Train_station%2C_Shefield.jpg/220px-Train_station%2C_Shefield.jpg]
[/wiki/File:Train_station,_Shefield.jpg] [/wiki/File:Train_station,_Shefield.jpg]Railway station, Sheffield 2013COACH[EDIT [/W/INDEX.PHP?TITLE=SHEFFIELD&ACTION=EDIT&SECTION=13]]
Coach [/wiki/Coach_(vehicle)] services running through Sheffield are operated by National Express [/wiki/National_Express_Coaches] 
and to a lesser extent Megabus [/wiki/Megabus_(Europe)], part of the Stagecoach Group [/wiki/Stagecoach_Group]. National Express
services call at Sheffield Interchange [/wiki/Sheffield_Interchange], Meadowhall Interchange and Meadowhead Bus Stop. Megabus
services only call at Meadowhall. National Express services 564, 560, 350, 320, 310 and 240 call at Sheffield, as do others on a
less frequent basis.[94] The 560/564 service is a direct connection to London Victoria Coach Station
[/wiki/Victoria_Coach_Station] via Chesterfield [/wiki/Chesterfield_coach_station] and Milton Keynes
[/wiki/Milton_Keynes_Coachway], operating 12 times a day in both directions. The 350 and 240 services connect Sheffield to 
Manchester Airport [/wiki/Manchester_Airport] and Heathrow [/wiki/Heathrow_Airport]/Gatwick [/wiki/Gatwick_Airport] Airports
respectively.[95] Two Megabus services, the M12 and M20, call at Sheffield en route to London from Newcastle upon Tyne
[/wiki/Newcastle_upon_Tyne] and Inverness [/wiki/Inverness] respectively.[96]

CANAL[EDIT [/W/INDEX.PHP?TITLE=SHEFFIELD&ACTION=EDIT&SECTION=14]]
The Sheffield and South Yorkshire Navigation [/wiki/Sheffield_and_South_Yorkshire_Navigation] (S&SY) is a system of navigable
inland waterways (canals [/wiki/Canal] and canalised rivers) in Yorkshire and Lincolnshire [/wiki/Lincolnshire].[97] Chiefly based
on the River Don [/wiki/River_Don,_South_Yorkshire], it runs for a length of 43 miles (69 km) and has 29locks [/wiki/Canal_lock].
It connects Sheffield, Rotherham [/wiki/Rotherham] and Doncaster [/wiki/Doncaster] with the River Trent [/wiki/River_Trent] at 
Keadby [/wiki/Keadby] and (via the New Junction Canal [/wiki/New_Junction_Canal]) the Aire and Calder Navigation
[/wiki/Aire_and_Calder_Navigation].[98]

AIR[EDIT [/W/INDEX.PHP?TITLE=SHEFFIELD&ACTION=EDIT&SECTION=15]]
Following the closure of Sheffield City Airport [/wiki/Sheffield_City_Airport] in 2008, the closest international airport to
Sheffield is Doncaster Sheffield Airport [/wiki/Doncaster_Sheffield_Airport] which is located 18 miles (29 km) from the city
centre. It operates on the site of the former RAF Finningley [/wiki/RAF_Finningley]. It opened on 28 April 2005 and is served
mainly by charter and budget airlines. It handles about one million passengers a year.[99]

A link road, opened in February 2016, connects Doncaster Sheffield Airport to the M18 motorway, reducing the journey time from
Sheffield city centre from 40 to 25 minutes.[100] East Midlands Airport [/wiki/East_Midlands_Airport] is within one hour's drive
of the city, and Manchester Airport [/wiki/Manchester_Airport] is connected directly to Sheffield by a direct train
[/wiki/South_TransPennine] every hour.

LOCAL TRAVEL[EDIT [/W/INDEX.PHP?TITLE=SHEFFIELD&ACTION=EDIT&SECTION=16]]
The start of the Sheffield Parkway, as viewed from Park Square, where it meets the City Centre. The road, in the centre, is six
lanes wide and leads towards the Parkway Edge development (left-centre) where the road meets the Inner Ring Road. To the right is
the Sheffield Supertram viaduct and beyond that a new apartment complex.
[//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d4/Sheffield_Parkway.png/220px-Sheffield_Parkway.png]
[/wiki/File:Sheffield_Parkway.png] [/wiki/File:Sheffield_Parkway.png]The Sheffield Parkway [/wiki/Sheffield_Parkway] terminus at 
Park Square [/wiki/Park_Square,_Sheffield]. The opposite end connects to the M1 motorway [/wiki/M1_motorway] at Junction 33.The A57 [/wiki/A57_road] and A61 roads [/wiki/A61_road] are the major trunk roads [/wiki/Trunk_road] through Sheffield.[90] These
run east–west and north–south respectively, crossing in the city centre, from where the other major roads generally radiate
spoke-like. An inner ring road [/wiki/Sheffield_Inner_Ring_Road], mostly constructed in the 1970s and extended in 2007 to form a
complete ring,[101] allows traffic to avoid the city centre, and an outer ring road [/wiki/Sheffield_Outer_Ring_Road] runs to the
east, south east and north, nearer the edge of the city, but does not serve the western side of Sheffield.[90]

Sheffield does not have as extensive a suburban and inter-urban railway network as other comparable British cities.[102] However,
there are several local rail routes running along the city's valleys and beyond, connecting it with other parts of South Yorkshire
[/wiki/South_Yorkshire], West Yorkshire [/wiki/West_Yorkshire], Nottinghamshire [/wiki/Nottinghamshire], Lincolnshire
[/wiki/Lincolnshire] and Derbyshire [/wiki/Derbyshire]. These local routes include the Penistone Line [/wiki/Penistone_Line], the 
Dearne Valley Line [/wiki/Dearne_Valley_Line], the Hope Valley Line [/wiki/Hope_Valley_Line] and the Hallam Line
[/wiki/Hallam_Line]. As well as the main stations of Sheffield [/wiki/Sheffield_Midland_station] and Meadowhall, there are five
suburban stations, at Chapeltown [/wiki/Chapeltown_railway_station], Darnall [/wiki/Darnall_railway_station], Woodhouse
[/wiki/Woodhouse_railway_station], and Dore and Totley [/wiki/Dore_railway_station].[103]

Sheffield Interchange, the main hub for bus and coach operations in Sheffield. In the foreground is the interchange itself.
Visible in the bottom left corner is the new, main entrance to the interchange. In the centre are the long bus stands that form
the interchange. Above that is the Digital Campus commercial development built upon an unused section of the interchange. In the
top left corner is the 1960s Park Hill flats development and to the right is Sheffield Railway Station.
[//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d6/Sheffield_Interchange_2.png/220px-Sheffield_Interchange_2.png]
[/wiki/File:Sheffield_Interchange_2.png] [/wiki/File:Sheffield_Interchange_2.png]Sheffield Interchange
[/wiki/Sheffield_Interchange]The Sheffield Supertram [/wiki/Sheffield_Supertram] (not derived from the previous tramways [/wiki/Sheffield_Tramway]), operated
by Stagecoach [/wiki/Stagecoach_Group], opened in 1994, shortly after the similar Metrolink [/wiki/Manchester_Metrolink] scheme in
Manchester. Its network consists of 37 miles (60 km) of track and three lines, from Halfway to Malin Bridge [/wiki/Malin_Bridge] 
(Blue Line), from Meadowhall to Middlewood [/wiki/Middlewood,_South_Yorkshire] (Yellow Line), and from Meadowhall to Herdings Park
[/wiki/Herdings_Park] (Purple Line), with all three lines running via the city centre.[104] The system contains both on-street and
segregated running, depending upon the section and line.

The Supertram serves as an important connection between areas in the North East of Sheffield (namely Meadowhall and Valley
Centertainment [/wiki/Valley_Centertainment]) and the city centre. Because it is operated by the Stagecoach Group
[/wiki/Stagecoach_Group], the ticketing system for the Supertram is integrated with Stagecoach buses in Sheffield, meaning
passengers can switch between the two modes of transport without having to buy a separate ticket.[105] The network is due to be
extended to Rotherham Parkgate [/wiki/Rotherham_Parkgate] by 2018, with a fleet of new "train-trams" sharing a conventional rail
line between Sheffield and Rotherham.

Sheffield's local bus infrastructure has its main hub at Sheffield Interchange [/wiki/Sheffield_Interchange]. Other bus stations
lie at Halfway [/wiki/Halfway,_Sheffield], Hillsborough [/wiki/Hillsborough,_South_Yorkshire] and Meadowhall. A flurry of new
operators was created after deregulation in 1986,[106] though a series of mergers has reduced the number.

A Sheffield Supertram in current blue, orange and red Stagecoach livery. The Tram shown is cross the Park Square junction. Behind
it is the bridge connecting the junction and tracks to Sheffield city centre. The whole square (now 20 years since redevelopment)
is covered in trees and plants and new buildings can be seen beyond them.
[//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2f/Sheffield_Supertram_2010.png/220px-Sheffield_Supertram_2010.png]
[/wiki/File:Sheffield_Supertram_2010.png] [/wiki/File:Sheffield_Supertram_2010.png]A Sheffield SupertramThere are numerous bus
operators within Sheffield: First South Yorkshire [/wiki/First_South_Yorkshire], Stagecoach Yorkshire [/wiki/Stagecoach_Yorkshire]
, TM Travel [/wiki/TM_Travel], Hulleys of Baslow [/wiki/Hulleys_of_Baslow], Powells, G&J Holmes and Sheffield Community Transport
[/wiki/Sheffield_Community_Transport]. First South Yorkshire, became by far the largest bus operator and in recent years
implemented a series of fare rises and service cuts which saw bus ridership drop.[107][108] Recent developments have seen 
Stagecoach Sheffield [/wiki/Stagecoach_Sheffield] taking over Yorkshire Terrier [/wiki/Yorkshire_Terrier_(bus_company)], Andrews
and parent company Yorkshire Traction [/wiki/Yorkshire_Traction], thus forming one company and in the process expanding their bus
services in the city. This has resulted in increased competition, and price drops on certain routes.[109] A zero-fare
[/wiki/Zero-fare] bus service, the FreeBee (Operated by First South Yorkshire [/wiki/First_South_Yorkshire]), operated a circular
route around the city centre from the Sheffield Interchange. The FreeBee buses stopped in 2014 and is due to save £8 million.[110] 
[111]

In 2008, the Bus Rapid Transit [/wiki/Bus_Rapid_Transit] Scheme between Sheffield and Rotherham [/wiki/Rotherham] was approved by
the Yorkshire and Humber Assembly [/wiki/Yorkshire_and_Humber_Assembly]'s Regional Transport Board. There are plans for two
routes; one (the Northern route) via Meadowhall and Templeborough [/wiki/Templeborough], and the other via the developing
employment centre and Waverley.[112]

CYCLING[EDIT [/W/INDEX.PHP?TITLE=SHEFFIELD&ACTION=EDIT&SECTION=17]]
For cycling, although hilly, Sheffield is compact and has few major trunk roads. It is on the Trans-Pennine Trail
[/wiki/Trans-Pennine_Trail], a National Cycle Network [/wiki/National_Cycle_Network] route running from West to East from 
Southport [/wiki/Southport] in Merseyside to Hornsea [/wiki/Hornsea] in the East Riding of Yorkshire
[/wiki/East_Riding_of_Yorkshire] and North to South from Leeds [/wiki/Leeds] in West Yorkshire to Chesterfield
[/wiki/Chesterfield] in Derbyshire.[113] There are many cycle routes going along country paths in the woods surrounding the city,
though very few cycle lanes in the city itself.

EDUCATION[EDIT [/W/INDEX.PHP?TITLE=SHEFFIELD&ACTION=EDIT&SECTION=18]]
Main article: Education in Sheffield [/wiki/Education_in_Sheffield]Blue/Grey skyscraper with a glass curtain wall. In the
foreground is park pond with a small wooden bridge and trees at either side. In between the Tower and the pond is a modern
2-storey building [//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/81/Sheffield_Arts_Tower.png/170px-Sheffield_Arts_Tower.png]
[/wiki/File:Sheffield_Arts_Tower.png] [/wiki/File:Sheffield_Arts_Tower.png]The Arts Tower [/wiki/Arts_Tower], on the University of
Sheffield [/wiki/University_of_Sheffield] campus
[//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/70/SheffieldHallamNight.jpg/220px-SheffieldHallamNight.jpg]
[/wiki/File:SheffieldHallamNight.jpg] [/wiki/File:SheffieldHallamNight.jpg]Hallam Square and the entrance to Sheffield Hallam
University's City CampusUNIVERSITIES AND COLLEGES[EDIT [/W/INDEX.PHP?TITLE=SHEFFIELD&ACTION=EDIT&SECTION=19]]
Sheffield has two universities, the University of Sheffield [/wiki/University_of_Sheffield] and Sheffield Hallam University
[/wiki/Sheffield_Hallam_University]. The two combined bring about 65,000 students to the city every year.[114][115][not in
citation given [/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability]] Sheffield University was established in 1897 as University College Sheffield and
became the University of Sheffield in 1905.

Sheffield Hallam University (SHU) is a university on two sites in Sheffield. City Campus is located in the city centre, close to
Sheffield railway station, and Collegiate Crescent [/wiki/Collegiate_Crescent] Campus is about two miles away, adjacent to 
Ecclesall Road [/wiki/Ecclesall_Road] in south-west Sheffield. The university is the third largest in the UK, with more than
37,000 students (of whom over 4,000 are international students), 4,170 staff and 747 courses. Sheffield Hallam University's
history goes back to 1843 with the establishment of the Sheffield School of Design. During the 1960s several independent colleges
(including the School of Design) joined to become Sheffield Polytechnic (Sheffield City Polytechnic from 1976) and was finally
renamed Sheffield Hallam University in 1992.

Sheffield has three main further education [/wiki/Further_education] providers, The Sheffield College [/wiki/Sheffield_College], 
Longley Park Sixth Form College [/wiki/Longley_Park_Sixth_Form_College] and Chapeltown Academy [/wiki/Chapeltown_Academy]. The 
Sheffield College [/wiki/Sheffield_College] is organised on a federal basis and was originally created from the merger of six
colleges around the city, since reduced to just four: Sheffield City (formerly Castle)[116] near the city centre, Hillsborough,
serving the north of the city and Norton and Peaks to the south.

SECONDARY, PRIMARY AND PRE-SCHOOL EDUCATION[EDIT [/W/INDEX.PHP?TITLE=SHEFFIELD&ACTION=EDIT&SECTION=20]]
See also: List of schools in Sheffield [/wiki/List_of_schools_in_Sheffield]There are 137 primary schools, 26 secondary schools –
of which 10 have sixth forms [/wiki/Sixth_form]: (High Storrs [/wiki/High_Storrs_School_(Sheffield)], King Ecgberts
[/wiki/King_Ecgbert_School], King Edward VII [/wiki/King_Edward_VII_School_(Sheffield)], Silverdale
[/wiki/Silverdale_School_(Sheffield)], Meadowhead [/wiki/Meadowhead_School], Tapton [/wiki/Tapton_School], UTC Sheffield
[/wiki/UTC_Sheffield], Notre Dame Catholic High [/wiki/Notre_Dame_School_(Sheffield)], Bradfield and All Saints Catholic High
[/wiki/All_Saints_Catholic_High_School,_Sheffield][117]) – and a sixth-form college, Longley Park Sixth Form College
[/wiki/Longley_Park_Sixth_Form_College].[118] The city's five independent private schools include Birkdale School
[/wiki/Birkdale_School] and the Sheffield High School [/wiki/Sheffield_High_School_(South_Yorkshire)].[119] There are also 12
special schools and a number of Integrated Resource Units in mainstream schools which are, along with all other schools, managed
by Sheffield City Council.[120] All schools are non-selective, mixed sex schools (apart from Sheffield High School
[/wiki/Sheffield_High_School,_South_Yorkshire] which is an all-girls school).[120] The Early Years Education and Childcare Service
of Sheffield City Council manages 32 nurseries and children's centres in the city.[120]

SPORT[EDIT [/W/INDEX.PHP?TITLE=SHEFFIELD&ACTION=EDIT&SECTION=21]]
Main article: Sport in Sheffield [/wiki/Sport_in_Sheffield]
[//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a5/BramallLaneKop.jpg/220px-BramallLaneKop.jpg] [/wiki/File:BramallLaneKop.jpg] 
[/wiki/File:BramallLaneKop.jpg]Bramall Lane [/wiki/Bramall_Lane], the home of Sheffield United [/wiki/Sheffield_United_F.C.], is
close to the city centreSheffield has a long sporting heritage. In 1857 a collective of cricketers [/wiki/Cricket] formed the world's first-ever official 
football [/wiki/Association_football] club, Sheffield F.C. [/wiki/Sheffield_F.C.],[121] and the world's second-ever, Hallam F.C.
[/wiki/Hallam_F.C.], who also play at the world's oldest football ground [/wiki/Sandygate_Road] in the suburb of Crosspool
[/wiki/Crosspool]. Sheffield and Hallam are today Sheffield's two major non-league sides, although Sheffield now play just outside
the city in nearby Dronfield [/wiki/Dronfield], Derbyshire. Sheffield and Hallam contest what has become known as the Sheffield
derby. By 1860 there were 15 football clubs in Sheffield, with the first ever amateur league and cup competitions taking place in
the city.[122]

[//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ed/Hillsborough_Stadium_interior.jpg/220px-Hillsborough_Stadium_interior.jpg]
[/wiki/File:Hillsborough_Stadium_interior.jpg] [/wiki/File:Hillsborough_Stadium_interior.jpg]Hillsborough
[/wiki/Hillsborough_Stadium], the home of Sheffield Wednesday [/wiki/Sheffield_Wednesday], is the city's largest stadium with a
capacity of just under 40,000Sheffield is best known for its two professional football teams, Sheffield United [/wiki/Sheffield_United_F.C.], known locally as
The Blades, and Sheffield Wednesday [/wiki/Sheffield_Wednesday_F.C.], known locally as The Owls. United, who play at Bramall Lane
[/wiki/Bramall_Lane] south of the city centre, and Wednesday, who play at Hillsborough [/wiki/Hillsborough_Stadium] in the north
west of the city, both now compete in the Football League Championship [/wiki/Football_League_Championship] following United's
promotion from League One [/wiki/League_One] at the end of the 2016-17 season [/wiki/2016%E2%80%9317_in_English_football] after a
six-year absence. The two clubs contest the Steel City Derby [/wiki/Steel_City_Derby], which is considered by many to be one of
the most fierce football rivalries in English Football.[123] In the pre-war era, both Wednesday and United enjoyed large amounts
of success and found themselves two of the country's top clubs; Sheffield Wednesday have been champions of the Football League
four times - in 1902–03 [/wiki/1902%E2%80%9303_Football_League], 1903–04 [/wiki/1903-04_Football_League], 1928–29
[/wiki/1928-29_Football_League] and 1929–30 [/wiki/1929-30_Football_League], whilst Sheffield United have won it once, in 1897–98
[/wiki/1897-98_Football_League]. During the 1970s and early 1980s the two sides fell from grace, with Wednesday finding themselves
in the Third Division [/wiki/Football_League_Third_Division] by the mid 70s and United as far as the Fourth Division
[/wiki/Football_League_Fourth_Division] in 1981 [/wiki/1980-81_in_English_football]. Wednesday once again became one of England's
high-flying clubs following promotion back to the First Division [/wiki/Football_League_First_Division] in 1984
[/wiki/1983-84_in_English_football], winning the League Cup in 1991 [/wiki/1991_Football_League_Cup_Final], competing in the UEFA
Cup in 1992–93 [/wiki/1992%E2%80%9393_UEFA_Cup], and reaching the final of both the League Cup
[/wiki/1993_Football_League_Cup_Final] and FA Cup [/wiki/1993_FA_Cup_Final] in the same season [/wiki/1992-93_in_English_football]
. United and Wednesday were both founding members of the Premier League [/wiki/FA_Premier_League] in 1992, but The Blades were
relegated in 1994 [/wiki/1993-94_in_English_football]. The Owls remained until 2000 [/wiki/1999-00_in_English_football]. Both
clubs have gone into decline in the 21st century, Wednesday twice relegated to League One [/wiki/Football_League_One] and United
suffering the same fate in 2011 [/wiki/2010-11_in_English_football], despite a brief spell in the Premier League in 2006–07
[/wiki/2006-07_in_English_football]. Sheffield Wednesday's new owner Dejphon Chansiri [/wiki/Dejphon_Chansiri] is aiming for
promotion back to the Premier League, which has currently resulted in two unsuccessful Play-Off campaigns but increased league
standings.[124]

[//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/PeleSheffield.jpg/170px-PeleSheffield.jpg] [/wiki/File:PeleSheffield.jpg] 
[/wiki/File:PeleSheffield.jpg]Brazilian legend Pelé [/wiki/Pel%C3%A9] (left) in Sheffield in November 2007, marking the 150th
anniversary of the world's oldest football club, Sheffield F.C. [/wiki/Sheffield_F.C.][6]Sheffield was the site of the deadliest
sports venue disaster in the United Kingdom, the Hillsborough disaster [/wiki/Hillsborough_disaster] in 1989, when 96 Liverpool
[/wiki/Liverpool_F.C.] supporters were killed in a stampede and crush during an FA Cup [/wiki/FA_Cup] semi final at the venue.

Rotherham United [/wiki/Rotherham_United_F.C.], who play in League One, did play their home games in the city between 2008 and
2012, having moved to play at Sheffield's Don Valley Stadium [/wiki/Don_Valley_Stadium] in 2008 following a dispute with their
previous landlord at their traditional home ground of Millmoor [/wiki/Millmoor], Rotherham. However, in July 2012, the club moved
to the new 12,000 seat New York Stadium [/wiki/New_York_Stadium] in Rotherham. There are also facilities for golf, climbing
[/wiki/Climbing] and bowling, as well as a newly inaugurated national ice-skating arena (IceSheffield [/wiki/IceSheffield]).

Sheffield Eagles [/wiki/Sheffield_Eagles] RLFC are the city's professional Rugby league [/wiki/Rugby_league] team who play their
matches at Owlerton Stadium [/wiki/Owlerton_Stadium]. They currently play in the second tier of the professional league, the 
Championship [/wiki/Co-operative_Championship] and are current champions, having won back to back titles in 2012 and 2013. Their
most successful moment came in 1998, when, against all the odds they defeated Wigan [/wiki/Wigan_Warriors] in the Challenge Cup
final, despite being huge underdogs. The team then hit troubled times before reforming in 2003. Since then they have played their
rugby in the Championship (second tier). In 2011, they made the playoffs finishing in fifth place. They made the Grand Final, by
defeating Leigh [/wiki/Leigh_Centurions], who were huge favourites in a playoff semi final. In the final, they were
comprehensively beaten by Featherstone Rovers [/wiki/Featherstone_Rovers]. Sheffield also put in a bid to be a host city for the 
2013 Rugby League World Cup [/wiki/2013_Rugby_League_World_Cup], but their bid was unsuccessful.

Sheffield is also home to the Sheffield Steelers [/wiki/Sheffield_Steelers] ice hockey team who play out of the 8,500 seater 
Sheffield Arena [/wiki/Sheffield_Arena]. They play in the 10 team professional Elite Ice Hockey League
[/wiki/Elite_Ice_Hockey_League]. Many of Sheffield's sporting facilities were built for the World Student Games
[/wiki/Universiade], which the city hosted in 1991, including Sheffield Arena and the Ponds Forge [/wiki/Ponds_Forge] 
international diving and swimming complex. Ponds Forge is also the home of Sheffield City Swimming Club
[/wiki/Sheffield_City_Swimming_Club], a local swimming club competing in the Speedo [/wiki/Speedo] league. The former Don Valley
International Athletics Stadium [/wiki/Don_Valley_Stadium], once the largest athletics stadium in the UK, was also constructed for
the Universiade games.[125] The Sheffield Ski Village [/wiki/Sheffield_Ski_Village] was the largest artificial ski [/wiki/Ski] 
resort in Europe, before being destroyed in a series of suspected arson attacks in 2012 and 2013. The city also has two indoor
climbing centres. Sheffield was the UK's first National City of Sport and is now home to the English Institute of Sport –
Sheffield [/wiki/English_Institute_of_Sport_%E2%80%93_Sheffield], where British athletes trained for the 2012 Olympics.[126]

Sheffield also has close ties with snooker [/wiki/Snooker], with the city's Crucible Theatre [/wiki/Crucible_Theatre] being the
venue for the World Snooker Championships [/wiki/World_Snooker_Championship].[127] The English Institute of Sport hosts most of
the top fencing competitions each year, including the National Championships for Seniors, Juniors (U20's) and Cadets (U17's) as
well as the 2011 Senior European Fencing Championships. The English squash [/wiki/Squash_(sport)] open is also held in the city
every year. The International Open and World Matchplay Championship bowls [/wiki/Bowls] tournaments have both been held at Ponds
Forge [/wiki/Ponds_Forge].[128] The city also hosts the Sheffield Tigers [/wiki/Sheffield_Tigers_RUFC] rugby union
[/wiki/Rugby_union], Sheffield Sharks [/wiki/Sheffield_Sharks], American Football team the Sheffield Giants
[/wiki/Sheffield_Giants], basketball, Sheffield University Bankers [/wiki/Sheffield_University_Bankers_Hockey_Club] hockey
[/wiki/Field_hockey], Sheffield Steelers [/wiki/Sheffield_Steelers] ice hockey [/wiki/Ice_hockey] and Sheffield Tigers
[/wiki/Sheffield_Tigers_(Speedway)] speedway [/wiki/Motorcycle_speedway] teams. Sheffield also has many golf courses all around
the city.

A Modern sporting facility. The building is roughly rectangular in shape and is quite modern, with a wooden clad design. It is
surrounded by greenery and has several tall, white spikes on its roof.
[//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9a/English_Institute_of_Sport_Sheffield.png/220px-English_Institute_of_Sport_Sheffield.png]
[/wiki/File:English_Institute_of_Sport_Sheffield.png] [/wiki/File:English_Institute_of_Sport_Sheffield.png]English Institute of
Sport, SheffieldSheffield was selected as a candidate host city by the Football Association (FA) [/wiki/The_FA] as part of the English 2018 and
2022 FIFA World Cup bid [/wiki/English_2018_and_2022_FIFA_World_Cup_bid] on 16 December 2009.[129] Hillsborough Stadium
[/wiki/Hillsborough_Stadium] was chosen as the proposed venue for matches in Sheffield.[130] The bid failed.

The National Hockey League [/wiki/National_Hockey_League]'s Stanley Cup [/wiki/Stanley_Cup] was made in Sheffield in 1892.
Sheffield is also home to the Sheffield Steel Rollergirls [/wiki/Sheffield_Steel_Rollergirls], a roller derby team.

Sheffield hosted the finish of Stage 2 of the 2014 Tour de France [/wiki/2014_Tour_de_France]. Within the City limits and located
just 4 kilometres (2.5 mi) from the finish, was the ninth and final climb of the stage, the Category 4 Côte de Jenkin Road. The
one point in the King of the Mountains [/wiki/King_of_the_Mountains] competition was claimed by Chris Froome [/wiki/Chris_Froome] 
of Team Sky [/wiki/Team_Sky]. The climb was just 0.8 kilometres (0.50 mi) long at an average gradient of 10.8%. The stage was won
by the eventual overall winner, Vincenzo Nibali [/wiki/Vincenzo_Nibali] of Astana Pro Team [/wiki/Astana_Pro_Team].[131]

CULTURE AND ATTRACTIONS[EDIT [/W/INDEX.PHP?TITLE=SHEFFIELD&ACTION=EDIT&SECTION=22]]
Main article: Culture of Sheffield [/wiki/Culture_of_Sheffield]Sheffield made the shortlist for the first city to be designated UK City of Culture [/wiki/UK_City_of_Culture], but in July 2010
it was announced that Derry [/wiki/Derry] had been selected.[132]

ATTRACTIONS[EDIT [/W/INDEX.PHP?TITLE=SHEFFIELD&ACTION=EDIT&SECTION=23]]
Main article: Visitor attractions in Sheffield [/wiki/Visitor_attractions_in_Sheffield]
[//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8b/Bishops_House_2011.jpg/220px-Bishops_House_2011.jpg]
[/wiki/File:Bishops_House_2011.jpg] [/wiki/File:Bishops_House_2011.jpg]Bishops' House
[//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1e/Mappin_Art_Gallery_Sheffield.jpg/220px-Mappin_Art_Gallery_Sheffield.jpg]
[/wiki/File:Mappin_Art_Gallery_Sheffield.jpg] [/wiki/File:Mappin_Art_Gallery_Sheffield.jpg]The Grade II* listed
[/wiki/Grade_II*_listed] Weston Park Museum [/wiki/Weston_Park_Museum]The Sheffield Walk of Fame [/wiki/Sheffield_Legends] in the City Centre honours famous Sheffield residents past and present in a
similar way to the Hollywood version.[133] Sheffield also had its own Ferris Wheel known as the Wheel of Sheffield
[/wiki/Wheel_of_Sheffield], located atop Fargate shopping precinct. The Wheel was dismantled in October 2010 and moved to London's
Hyde Park.[134] Heeley City Farm and Graves Park [/wiki/Graves_Park] are home to Sheffield's two farm animal collections, both of
which are fully open to the public.[135][136] Sheffield also has its own zoo; the Tropical Butterfly House, Wildlife & Falconry
Centre.[137]

There are about 1,100 listed buildings in Sheffield [/wiki/Listed_buildings_in_Sheffield] (including the whole of the Sheffield
postal district [/wiki/S_postcode_area]).[138] Of these, only five are Grade I listed. Fifty-nine are Grade II*, but the
overwhelming majority are listed as Grade II.[139] Compared to other English cities, Sheffield has few buildings with the highest
Grade I listing: Liverpool [/wiki/Liverpool], for example, has 26 Grade I [/wiki/Listed_buildings_in_Liverpool] listed buildings
[/wiki/Listed_building]. This situation led the noted architecture historian Nikolaus Pevsner [/wiki/Nikolaus_Pevsner], writing in
1959, to comment that the city was "architecturally a miserable disappointment", with no pre-19th-century buildings of any
distinction.[140] By contrast, in November 2007, Sheffield's Peace and Winter Gardens beat London's South Bank to gain the Royal
Institute of British Architects [/wiki/Royal_Institute_of_British_Architects]' Academy of Urbanism "Great Place" Award, as an
"outstanding example of how cities can be improved, to make urban spaces as attractive and accessible as possible".[141] In the
summer of 2016 a public art event across the city occurred called the Herd of Sheffield [/wiki/Herd_of_Sheffield] which raised
£410,000 for the Sheffield Children's Hospital [/wiki/Sheffield_Children%27s_Hospital].[142]

MUSIC[EDIT [/W/INDEX.PHP?TITLE=SHEFFIELD&ACTION=EDIT&SECTION=24]]
See also: List of musicians from Sheffield [/wiki/List_of_musicians_from_Sheffield]
[//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0f/The_Sheffield_Arena.jpg/220px-The_Sheffield_Arena.jpg]
[/wiki/File:The_Sheffield_Arena.jpg] [/wiki/File:The_Sheffield_Arena.jpg]Sheffield ArenaSheffield has been home to several
well-known bands and musicians, with a notably large number of synthpop [/wiki/Synthpop] and other electronic
[/wiki/Electronic_music] bands originating from the city.[143] These include The Human League [/wiki/The_Human_League], Heaven 17
[/wiki/Heaven_17], ABC [/wiki/ABC_(band)] and the more industrially [/wiki/Industrial_music] inclined Cabaret Voltaire
[/wiki/Cabaret_Voltaire_(band)] & Clock DVA [/wiki/Clock_DVA]. This electronic tradition has continued: techno
[/wiki/Techno_music] label Warp Records [/wiki/Warp_Records] was a central pillar of the Yorkshire Bleeps and Bass
[/wiki/Yorkshire_Bleeps_and_Bass] scene of the early 1990s, and has gone on to become one of the UK's oldest and best-loved dance
music labels. More recently, other popular genres of electronic music such as bassline house [/wiki/Bassline_house] have
originated in the city.[144] Sheffield was once home to a number of historically important nightclubs in the early dance music
scene of the 1980s and 1990s, Gatecrasher One [/wiki/Gatecrasher] was one of the most popular clubs in the North of England until
its destruction by fire on 18 June 2007.[145]

A number of major music acts, including Joe Cocker [/wiki/Joe_Cocker], Def Leppard [/wiki/Def_Leppard], Paul Carrack
[/wiki/Paul_Carrack] (of Mike + The Mechanics [/wiki/Mike_%2B_The_Mechanics]), Arctic Monkeys [/wiki/Arctic_Monkeys], Bring Me the
Horizon [/wiki/Bring_Me_the_Horizon], Pulp [/wiki/Pulp_(band)] and Moloko [/wiki/Moloko], hail from the city.[146][147][148][149] 
Indie [/wiki/Indie_(music)] band The Long Blondes [/wiki/The_Long_Blondes] originated from the city,[150] as part of what the NME
[/wiki/NME] dubbed the New Yorkshire [/wiki/New_Yorkshire] scene.[151]

Sheffield City Hall, a Neo-classical design with a large portico and prominent pillars which were damaged when a bomb fell on the
adjoining Barkers Pool during the Second World War. It is a grade II* listed building
[//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8b/Sheffield_city_hall_2.png/220px-Sheffield_city_hall_2.png]
[/wiki/File:Sheffield_city_hall_2.png] [/wiki/File:Sheffield_city_hall_2.png]Sheffield City Hall, a Grade II* listed buildingIn
1999, the National Centre for Popular Music [/wiki/National_Centre_for_Popular_Music], a museum dedicated to the subject of 
popular music [/wiki/Popular_music], was opened in the city.[152] It was not as successful as was hoped, however, and later
evolved to become a live music venue; then in February 2005, the unusual steel-covered building became the students' union
[/wiki/Students%27_union] for Sheffield Hallam University [/wiki/Sheffield_Hallam_University].[153] Live music venues in the city
include the Harley Hotel, Leadmill [/wiki/Leadmill], West Street Live, the Boardwalk [/wiki/Boardwalk_(nightclub)], Dove &
Rainbow, The Casbah, The Cremorne [/wiki/The_Cremorne,_Sheffield], Corporation [/wiki/Corporation_(nightclub)], New Barrack
Tavern, The Broadfield Hotel, Redstone bar and nightclub, the City Hall [/wiki/Sheffield_City_Hall], the University of Sheffield
Students' Union [/wiki/University_of_Sheffield_Students%27_Union], the Studio Theatre at the Crucible Theatre
[/wiki/Crucible_Theatre], the O2 Academy Sheffield [/wiki/O2_Academy_Sheffield] and The Grapes [/wiki/The_Grapes,_Sheffield].[154]
[155][156][157][158][159]

Sheffield hosts a number of festivals, the Grin Up North Sheffield Comedy Festival,[160] the Sensoria Music & Film Festival
[/wiki/Sensoria_Music_%26_Film_Festival] and the Tramlines Festival [/wiki/Tramlines_Festival]. The Tramlines Festival was
launched as an annual music festival in 2009,[161] it is held throughout venues in Sheffield City Centre
[/wiki/Sheffield_City_Centre], and features local and national artists.[162] The city is also home to several local orchestras and
choirs, such as the Sheffield Symphony Orchestra [/wiki/Sheffield_Symphony_Orchestra], the Sheffield Philharmonic Orchestra
[/wiki/Sheffield_Philharmonic_Orchestra], the Sheffield Chamber Orchestra [/wiki/Sheffield_Chamber_Orchestra], the City of
Sheffield Youth Orchestra [/wiki/City_of_Sheffield_Youth_Orchestra], the Sheffield Philharmonic Chorus
[/wiki/Sheffield_Philharmonic_Chorus] and the Chorus UK [/wiki/Chorus_UK] community choir.[163][164][165][166]

THEATRES[EDIT [/W/INDEX.PHP?TITLE=SHEFFIELD&ACTION=EDIT&SECTION=25]]
[//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/52/Sheffield_Crucible_theatre.png/220px-Sheffield_Crucible_theatre.png]
[/wiki/File:Sheffield_Crucible_theatre.png] [/wiki/File:Sheffield_Crucible_theatre.png]The Crucible Theatre
[/wiki/Crucible_Theatre] (centre) and Lyceum Theatre (right)Sheffield has two large theatres, the Lyceum Theatre [/wiki/Lyceum_Theatre_(Sheffield)] and the Crucible Theatre
[/wiki/Crucible_Theatre], which together with the smaller Studio Theatre [/wiki/Studio_Theatre_(Sheffield)] make up the largest
theatre complex outside London, located in Tudor Square [/wiki/Tudor_Square].[167] The Crucible Theatre is the home (since 1977)
of the World Snooker Championships [/wiki/World_Snooker_Championships] and hosts many well-known stage productions throughout the
year. The Lyceum, which opened in 1897, serves as a venue for touring West End productions [/wiki/West_End_theatre] and operas by 
Opera North [/wiki/Opera_North], as well as locally produced shows. Sheffield also has the Montgomery Theatre, a small 420 seater
theatre located a short distance from Tudor Square, opposite the town hall on Surrey Street.[168] There are also a large number of
smaller amateur theatres scattered throughout the city.

MUSEUMS[EDIT [/W/INDEX.PHP?TITLE=SHEFFIELD&ACTION=EDIT&SECTION=26]]
Sheffield's museums are managed by two distinct organisations. Museums Sheffield [/wiki/Museums_Sheffield] manages the Weston Park
Museum [/wiki/Weston_Park_Museum] (a Grade II* listed Building), Millennium Galleries [/wiki/Millennium_Galleries] and Graves Art
Gallery [/wiki/Graves_Art_Gallery].[169] Sheffield Industrial Museums Trust [/wiki/Sheffield_Industrial_Museums_Trust] manages the
museums dedicated to Sheffield's industrial heritage of which there are three.[170] Kelham Island Museum
[/wiki/Kelham_Island_Museum] (located just to the North of the city centre) showcases the city's history of steel manufacturing.
[171] Abbeydale Industrial Hamlet [/wiki/Abbeydale_Industrial_Hamlet] (in the south of the city) is a Grade I Listed building and
a Scheduled Ancient Monument [/wiki/Scheduled_Ancient_Monument].[172] Shepherd Wheel [/wiki/Shepherd_Wheel] (in the south-East of
the city) is a former water-powered grinding workshop [/wiki/Workshop], Grade II listed and a Scheduled Ancient Monument.[173]

GREENSPACE[EDIT [/W/INDEX.PHP?TITLE=SHEFFIELD&ACTION=EDIT&SECTION=27]]
[//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/Sheffield_Winter_Gardens_%26_St._Paul%27s_Tower.jpg/220px-Sheffield_Winter_Gardens_%26_St._Paul%27s_Tower.jpg]
[/wiki/File:Sheffield_Winter_Gardens_%26_St._Paul%27s_Tower.jpg] [/wiki/File:Sheffield_Winter_Gardens_%26_St._Paul%27s_Tower.jpg]
Sheffield Winter Gardens & St. Paul's TowerSheffield has a reputed 2 million trees and has been described as the greenest city in
Europe,[174] despite a large number of highway tree fellings taking place across the city since 2012.[175] There are many parks
and woods throughout the city and beyond. There are 83 parks in Sheffield (13 'City' Parks, 20 'District' Parks and 50 'Local'
Parks) which are located throughout the city. Included in the city parks category are 3 of Sheffield's 6 public gardens (The 
Sheffield Botanical Gardens [/wiki/Sheffield_Botanical_Gardens], The Peace Gardens [/wiki/Peace_Gardens] and Hillsborough Walled
Gardens, with the Sheffield Winter Gardens [/wiki/Sheffield_Winter_Gardens], Beauchief Gardens [/wiki/Beauchief_Gardens] and
Lynwood Gardens being the separate entities).

The Sheffield Botanical Gardens are on a 19-acre site located to the south west of the city centre and date back to 1836. The site
includes a large, Grade II listed, Victorian era glasshouse [/wiki/Greenhouse]. The Peace Gardens, neighboured next to the Town
Hall [/wiki/Sheffield_Town_Hall] and forming part of the Heart of the City project, occupy a 0.67 hectares (1.7 acres) site in the
centre of the city. The site is dominated by its water features, principal among which is the Goodwin Fountain. Made up of 89
individual jets of water, this fountain lies at the corner of the quarter-circle shaped Peace Gardens and is named after Stuart
Goodwin [/wiki/Stuart_Goodwin], a notable Sheffield industrialist. Since their redevelopment in 1998, the Peace gardens have
received a number of regional and national accolades.[176] Hillsborough Walled Garden is located in Hillsborough Park
[/wiki/Hillsborough_Park], to the north-west of the city centre. The gardens date back to 1779 and have been dedicated to the
victims of the Hillsborough Disaster [/wiki/Hillsborough_Disaster] since the redevelopment of the gardens in the early 1990s.[177] 
The Winter Garden [/wiki/Sheffield_Winter_Garden], lying within the Heart of the City [/wiki/Heart_of_the_City_(development)], is
a large wood framed, glass skinned greenhouse [/wiki/Greenhouse] housing some 2,500 plants from around the world.[178]

[//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2d/Sheffield_Winter_Garden_-_inside.jpg/220px-Sheffield_Winter_Garden_-_inside.jpg]
[/wiki/File:Sheffield_Winter_Garden_-_inside.jpg] [/wiki/File:Sheffield_Winter_Garden_-_inside.jpg]Sheffield Winter Garden –
inside 2013Also within the city there are a number of nature reserves [/wiki/Nature_reserves] which when combined occupy 1,600 acres (6.5 km2
) of land.[179] There are also 170 woodland [/wiki/Woodland] areas within the city, 80 of which are classed as ancient.[179]

The South West boundary of the city overlaps with the Peak District National Park [/wiki/Peak_District], the first national park
in England (est. 1951).[180] As a consequence, several communities actually reside within both entities. The Peak District is home
to many notable, natural, features and also man-made features such as Chatsworth House [/wiki/Chatsworth_House], the setting for
the BBC series Pride and Prejudice [/wiki/Pride_and_Prejudice].[181]

Sheffield City Council [/wiki/Sheffield_City_Council] has created a new chain of parks spanning the hillside behind Sheffield
Station [/wiki/Sheffield_Station]. The park, known as Sheaf Valley Park, has an open-air amphitheatre and will include an
arboretum.[182] The site was once home to a medieval deer park, latterly owned by the Duke of Norfolk
[/wiki/Norfolk_Heritage_Park].[182]

ENTERTAINMENT[EDIT [/W/INDEX.PHP?TITLE=SHEFFIELD&ACTION=EDIT&SECTION=28]]
[//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Meadowhall_Shopping_Centre_-_The_Oasis_07-04.jpg/220px-Meadowhall_Shopping_Centre_-_The_Oasis_07-04.jpg]
[/wiki/File:Meadowhall_Shopping_Centre_-_The_Oasis_07-04.jpg] [/wiki/File:Meadowhall_Shopping_Centre_-_The_Oasis_07-04.jpg]The
Oasis food court at Meadowhall Centre [/wiki/Meadowhall_Centre]Sheffield has six cinema complexes, four of which are in the city
centre and a further two in the Lower Don Valley. One of these complexes is located at Valley Centertainment
[/wiki/Valley_Centertainment], a leisure and entertainment complex in the Don Valley [/wiki/Lower_Don_Valley]. It was built on
land previously occupied by steel mills [/wiki/Steel_mills] near what is now Meadowhall and the Sheffield Arena. It is home to
several restaurants, bars, a cinema [/wiki/Cineworld] multiplex [/wiki/Megaplex] and a bowling alley [/wiki/Bowling].[183] It is
also the largest Cineworld complex in the United Kingdom, containing 20 screens in one building.[184] Odeon Sheffield
[/wiki/Odeon_Sheffield], situated on Arundel Gate in the city Centre and Vue [/wiki/Vue_(cinema)], located within Meadowhall
Shopping Centre, are the two other mainstream cinemas in the city. The Showroom [/wiki/Showroom_Cinema,_Sheffield], an independent
cinema showing non-mainstream productions, is located in Sheaf Square [/wiki/Sheaf_Square], close to Sheffield station
[/wiki/Sheffield_station]. In 2002 the Showroom was voted as the best Independent cinema in the country by Guardian readers.[185] 
A Curzon Cinemas [/wiki/Curzon_Cinemas] complex has also recently opened in the city centre, close to the existing Odeon complex.
The cinema is based in the former Sheffield Banking Company building, located just off Arundel Gate. The cinema features 4K
resolution [/wiki/4K_resolution] projectors and was opened in January 2015.[186][187]

Sheffield has a thriving poetry and spoken word scene: from Wordlife's [http://opusindependents.com/wordlife/] events across the
city to the sustained work of Sheffield Authors [http://www.sheffieldauthors.co.uk]; from the vibrant monthly arts night, Verse
Matters [https://versematters.wordpress.com], at the Moor Theatre Deli [https://versematters.wordpress.com] to the longstanding
work of The Poetry Business [http://www.poetrybusiness.co.uk], there's always opportunities for new and experienced writers to get
writing and to share their work.

Owing to its long history, Sheffield has a large number of pubs [/wiki/Pubs] throughout the city. West Street, running through the
heart of the West End [/wiki/West_End,_Sheffield] district of the city centre, is home to many pubs, bars and clubs and attracts
many student visitors. A recent addition to the city's nightlife is Leopold Square [/wiki/Leopold_Square], situated just off the
northern end of West Street. Aagrah, an Indian restaurant in the square which serves Kashmiri cuisine [/wiki/Kashmiri_cuisine],
has recently been voted "Best Restaurant Group in the UK" at the prestigious British Curry Awards [/wiki/British_Curry_Awards].
[188]

MEDIA AND FILM[EDIT [/W/INDEX.PHP?TITLE=SHEFFIELD&ACTION=EDIT&SECTION=29]]
Sheffield has two commercial newspapers, The Star [/wiki/Sheffield_Star] and Sheffield Telegraph [/wiki/Sheffield_Telegraph], both
published by Johnston Press PLC [/wiki/Johnston_Press]. The Star has been published daily since 1897; the Sheffield Telegraph, now
a weekly publication, originated in 1855.[189]

Sheffield has its own TV station; Sheffield Live TV [/wiki/Sheffield_Live!], a not-for-profit company which began broadcasting on
23 September 2014.[190] SLTV has been awarded a 12-year licence to provide the digital terrestrial broadcasting service.[191][192]
[193] Regional broadcasters BBC Yorkshire [/wiki/BBC_Yorkshire] and Yorkshire Television [/wiki/Yorkshire_Television] also cover
the city. Five local radio stations broadcast in the city. The professional services are BBC Radio Sheffield
[/wiki/BBC_Radio_Sheffield], the independent Hallam FM [/wiki/Hallam_FM] and its sister station Magic AM [/wiki/Magic_AM].
Sheffield is also home to two FM [/wiki/FM_broadcasting] licensed community radio [/wiki/Community_radio] stations: Sheffield Live
93.2, and Burngreave Community Radio [/wiki/Burngreave_Community_Radio] on 103.1.

Sheffield Hospital Radio (Hospital Broadcasting Sheffield) broadcasts a 24-hour service to the Royal Hallamshire, Jessop Wing,
Northern General and Weston Park Hospital and also offers a dedicated patient visiting service. The charity is operated by
volunteers from studios at the Royal Hallamshire Hospital and is provided free to bedside terminals via Hospedia and on medium
wave 1431am from a transmitter at the Northern General Hospital.[194]

The films and plays The Full Monty [/wiki/The_Full_Monty], Threads [/wiki/Threads], Looks and Smiles
[/wiki/Looks_and_Smiles_(film)], When Saturday Comes [/wiki/When_Saturday_Comes_(film)], Whatever Happened to Harold Smith?
[/wiki/Whatever_Happened_to_Harold_Smith%3F], The History Boys [/wiki/The_History_Boys] and Four Lions [/wiki/Four_Lions] are set
in the city.[195] F.I.S.T. [/wiki/F.I.S.T.], Kill List [/wiki/Kill_List] and The Princess Bride [/wiki/The_Princess_Bride_(film)] 
also include several scenes filmed in Sheffield and a substantial part of Among Giants [/wiki/Among_Giants][196] was filmed in the
city. The documentary festival Sheffield Doc/Fest [/wiki/Sheffield_Doc/Fest] has been run annually since 1994 at the Showroom
Cinema [/wiki/Showroom_Cinema],[197] and in 2007 Sheffield hosted the Awards of the International Indian Film Academy
[/wiki/Awards_of_the_International_Indian_Film_Academy].[198]

FOLK CULTURE[EDIT [/W/INDEX.PHP?TITLE=SHEFFIELD&ACTION=EDIT&SECTION=30]]
Sheffield has a thriving folk music, song and dance community. Singing and music sessions occur weekly in many pubs around the
city and it also hosts the annual Sheffield Sessions Festival.[199] The University of Sheffield [/wiki/University_of_Sheffield] 
runs a number of courses and research projects dedicated to folk culture.[200]

The tradition of singing carols in pubs around Christmas is still kept alive in the city. The Sheffield Carols, as they are known
locally, predate modern carols by over a century and are sung with alternative words and verses.[201] Although there is a core of
carols that are sung at most venues, each particular place has its own mini-tradition. The repertoire at two nearby places can
vary widely, and woe betide those who try to strike up a ‘foreign’ carol. Some are unaccompanied, some have a piano or organ,
there is a flip chart with the words on in one place, a string quartet (quintet, sextet, septet) accompanies the singing at
another, some encourage soloists, others stick to audience participation, a brass band plays at certain events, the choir takes
the lead at another.[202] It is thought this tradition is now unique in Britain.

The city is home to thirteen morris dance [/wiki/Morris_dance] teams - thought to be one of the highest concentration of sides in
the country. Nearly all forms of the dance are represented in the city, including Cotswold [/wiki/Cotswold_morris] (Five Rivers
Morris,[203] Pecsaetan Morris,[204] Harthill Morris,[205] Lord Conyer's Morris Men,[206] Sheffield City Morris,[207] William
Morris[208]), border [/wiki/Border_Morris] (Boggart's Breakfast[209]), North West [/wiki/North_West_morris] (Yorkshire Chandelier,
[210] Silkstone Greens,[211] Lizzie Dripping[212]), rapper [/wiki/Rapper_dance] (Sheffield Steel Rapper[213]) and Yorkshire
Longsword [/wiki/Long_Sword_dance].

PUBLIC SERVICES[EDIT [/W/INDEX.PHP?TITLE=SHEFFIELD&ACTION=EDIT&SECTION=31]]
[//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/49/Royal_Hallamshire_Hospital.jpg/220px-Royal_Hallamshire_Hospital.jpg]
[/wiki/File:Royal_Hallamshire_Hospital.jpg] [/wiki/File:Royal_Hallamshire_Hospital.jpg]The Royal Hallamshire Hospital
[/wiki/Royal_Hallamshire_Hospital]Sheffield is policed by South Yorkshire Police [/wiki/South_Yorkshire_Police] (a territorial police force
[/wiki/Territorial_police_force]) whose headquarters are in the city. Sheffield constitutes one of its four Basic Command Units
(Barnsley, Doncaster and Rotherham being the other three).[214] The force polices an area of approximately 1,554 square kilometres
and is the 13th largest force in England, Wales and Northern Ireland [/wiki/Police_forces_in_the_United_Kingdom]. The force has in
its possession one Police helicopter [/wiki/Police_helicopter], known as Sierra Yankee 99.[215]

Medical services in Sheffield are provided by three NHS Foundation Trusts. Sheffield Teaching Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust
[/wiki/Sheffield_Teaching_Hospitals_NHS_Foundation_Trust] provides healthcare to people (primarily adults) throughout Sheffield
and South Yorkshire. The trusts title includes the word 'teaching' because it undertakes training of medical students at the 
University of Sheffield [/wiki/University_of_Sheffield] and has strong links to Sheffield Hallam University
[/wiki/Sheffield_Hallam_University] as well. The trust has two campuses: The West Campus containing the Royal Hallamshire Hospital
[/wiki/Royal_Hallamshire_Hospital], the Jessop Wing (maternity wing), Weston Park Hospital [/wiki/Weston_Park_Hospital] 
(specialist cancer treatment) and Charles Clifford Dental Hospital. The Northern General Hospital
[/wiki/Northern_General_Hospital] is the second 'campus' and is a large facility in the northern suburbs of Sheffield, containing
the city's A&E department. Sheffield Children's NHS Foundation Trust [/wiki/Sheffield_Children%27s_NHS_Foundation_Trust] provides
healthcare for children within the city of Sheffield, South Yorkshire and the UK as a whole.[216]

Sheffield Health and Social Care NHS Foundation Trust provides mental health services, services for people with learning
disabilities, substance misuse services, long term neurological conditions, as well as a consortium of GP practises.[217] The
Sheffield Institute for Motor Neurone Disease (also known as Sheffield Institute for Translational Neuroscience – SITraN) has been
developed by the University of Sheffield.[218]

Ambulances are provided by the Yorkshire Ambulance Service [/wiki/Yorkshire_Ambulance_Service], which itself is an NHS trust.[219] 
Fire services in Sheffield are provided by South Yorkshire Fire and Rescue Service [/wiki/South_Yorkshire_Fire_and_Rescue_Service]
. For the purposes of fire-fighting and rescue, Sheffield is divided into East and West sub-divisions.[220]

Domestic waste services in Sheffield are provided by Veolia Environmental Services under contract from and on behalf of the
council. Domestic recycling services were recently improved with the addition of glass recycling bins for each home.[citation
needed [/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed]] Council owned/run buildings are maintained by Kier Group Sheffield [/wiki/Kier_Group] in
partnership with the council.[citation needed [/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed]]

SISTER CITIES[EDIT [/W/INDEX.PHP?TITLE=SHEFFIELD&ACTION=EDIT&SECTION=32]]
The "Sheffield International Linking Committee" promotes Sheffield overseas, especially with five sister cities
[/wiki/Town_twinning]:[221]

 * China
   [//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/Flag_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China.svg/23px-Flag_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China.svg.png]
   [/wiki/China] Chengdu [/wiki/Chengdu], China
 * China
   [//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/Flag_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China.svg/23px-Flag_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China.svg.png]
   [/wiki/China] Anshan [/wiki/Anshan], China
 * Germany [//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/ba/Flag_of_Germany.svg/23px-Flag_of_Germany.svg.png] [/wiki/Germany] 
   Bochum [/wiki/Bochum], Germany
 * Ukraine [//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/49/Flag_of_Ukraine.svg/23px-Flag_of_Ukraine.svg.png] [/wiki/Ukraine] 
   Donetsk [/wiki/Donetsk], Ukraine
 * Nicaragua [//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/19/Flag_of_Nicaragua.svg/23px-Flag_of_Nicaragua.svg.png]
   [/wiki/Nicaragua] Estelí [/wiki/Estel%C3%AD], Nicaragua

A further four cities have a Friendship Agreement with Sheffield:

 * Japan [//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/9e/Flag_of_Japan.svg/23px-Flag_of_Japan.svg.png] [/wiki/Japan] Kawasaki
   [/wiki/Kawasaki,_Kanagawa], Japan
 * Zambia [//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/06/Flag_of_Zambia.svg/23px-Flag_of_Zambia.svg.png] [/wiki/Zambia] 
   Kitwe [/wiki/Kitwe], Zambia
 * Pakistan [//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/32/Flag_of_Pakistan.svg/23px-Flag_of_Pakistan.svg.png]
   [/wiki/Pakistan] Kotli [/wiki/Kotli], Pakistan-administered Kashmir [/wiki/Azad_Kashmir]
 * United States
   [//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/a/a4/Flag_of_the_United_States.svg/23px-Flag_of_the_United_States.svg.png]
   [/wiki/United_States] Pittsburgh [/wiki/Pittsburgh], United States

Two roads in Sheffield have been named after sister cities; a section of the A6102 in Norton is named Bochum Parkway, and a road
in Hackenthorpe [/wiki/Hackenthorpe] is named Donetsk Way. Likewise in Bochum, Germany there is a major road called the
Sheffield-Ring.

 10.  ^ The word Wales derives from the Germanic word Walhaz [/wiki/Walhaz], and was originally used by the Anglo-Saxons to refer
      to the native Britons. In reference to the villages of Wales and Waleswood, S.O. Addy [/wiki/Sidney_Oldall_Addy], in his A
      Glossary of Words Used in the Neighbourhood of Sheffield, p. 274, states "The Anglo-Saxon invaders or settlers called the
      old inhabitants or aborigines of this country wealas, or foreigners." See also, "Welsh" in Simpson, Jacqueline; Roud,
      Stephen (1989). Oxford English Dictionary [/wiki/Oxford_English_Dictionary]. Clarendon Press [/wiki/Clarendon_Press]. ISBN
      [/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number]0-19-210019-X [/wiki/Special:BookSources/0-19-210019-X].

      Northumbrians as far as Dore, where they met him, and offered terms of obedience and subjection, on the acceptance of which
      they returned home" (transcription [http://omacl.org/Anglo/part2.html]). Most sources (for example Vickers, Old Sheffield
      Town) state that the date given in the chronicle is incorrect, and that 829 is the more likely date for this event.

 73.  ^ There are numerous sources showing the international reputation of Sheffield for metallurgy, and in particular steel and
      cutlery manufacture. Some examples are: the Oxford English Dictionary [/wiki/Oxford_English_Dictionary], which begins its
      entry for Sheffield, "The name of a manufacturing city of Yorkshire, famous for cutlery"; and the Encyclopædia Britannica
      [/wiki/Encyclop%C3%A6dia_Britannica], which in its entry for "Sheffield" states that by 1830 Sheffield had earned
      "recognition as the world centre of high-grade steel manufacture". David Hey [/wiki/David_Hey] in the preface to his 1997
      book Mesters to Masters: A History of the Company of Cutlers in Hallamshire. (Oxford University Press
      [/wiki/Oxford_University_Press], ISBN [/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number]0-19-828997-9
      [/wiki/Special:BookSources/0-19-828997-9]) states "It (Sheffield) was known for its cutlery wares long before the
      incorporation of the Cutlers' Company [/wiki/Company_of_Cutlers_in_Hallamshire] in 1624, and long before it acquired an
      international reputation as the steel capital of the world."

Crucible Sheffield [/content/images/crucible.jpg] VISIT SHEFFIELD Sheffield is a vibrant city bursting with character and
creativity. Search for things to do and find out what's on to make the most of your visit. Find out more [/visit] Conference
Sheffield [/content/images/conference.jpg] CONFERENCE SHEFFIELD Find everything you need to plan and deliver a conference or event
in Sheffield and the surrounding area, whatever stage you are at in your planning. Find out more [/conference] Sheffield station
[/content/images/sheffield-station.jpg] BUSINESS SHEFFIELD Businesses thrive in Sheffield because people thrive in Sheffield. Find
out how we can help you set up and grow your business. Find out more [/business] Sheffield building [/content/images/building.jpg]
INVEST SHEFFIELD Relocating your business? We can help you locate and expand in Sheffield. We also offer aftercare support to
recent investors & foreign-owned companies. Find out more [/invest]  * Accessibilty [/accessibility]

    * 
   
   Want to pay for something not in the list above?See more payments [/content/sheffield/home/pay.html]

   The easiest way to communicate with us is through this website. You'll get a quicker response.
