Summary League Table Performance Reviews Living Here Fees & Finance Sport & Exercise Summary MBA Summary  * 
 *  Entry Standards Entry Standards The average UCAS tariff score of new students entering the University. These tables use the
   old UCAS tariff. 
   
   Read more [/league-tables/methodology/] 407 
 * 
 *  Student Satisfaction Student Satisfaction A guide to how satisfied students are with the quality of teaching they receive. 
   
   Read more [/league-tables/methodology/] 4.11 / 5.00 
 * 
 *  Research Quality Research Quality A measure of the quality of the research undertaken in the University. 
   
   Read more [/league-tables/methodology/] 3.17 / 4.00 
 * 
 *  Research Intensity Research Intensity A measure of the proportion of staff involved in high-quality research in the
   University. 
   
   Read more [/league-tables/methodology/] 0.74 / 1.00 
 * 
 *  Graduate Prospects Graduate Prospects A guide to the employability of graduates on completion of their courses at the
   University. 
   
   Read more [/league-tables/methodology/] 81.2 / 100.0 
 * 
 *  Student-Staff Ratio Student-Staff Ratio The average staffing levels at the University. 
   
   Read more [/league-tables/methodology/] 14.6 
 * 
 *  Academic Services Spend Academic Services Spend A guide to how much the University spends on supporting services such as
   libraries and IT. 
   
   Read more [/league-tables/methodology/] 1,621 
 * 
 *  Facilities Spend Facilities Spend A guide to how much the University spends on supporting facilities such as the careers
   service, health and counselling services and sport facilities. 
   
   Read more [/league-tables/methodology/] 509 
 * 
 *  Good Honours Good Honours The percentage of graduates achieving a first or upper second class honours degree – the class of
   degree achieved can impact a graduate’s employment prospects. 
   
   Read more [/league-tables/methodology/] 80.0 / 100.0 
 * 
 *  Degree Completion Degree Completion The proportion of students expected to successfully complete their studies and gain a
   degree from the University. 
   
   Read more [/league-tables/methodology/] 94.4 / 100.0 
 * 

The University of Sheffield is a leading Russell Group university, founded over 100 years ago. It is renowned for the excellence,
impact and distinctiveness of its research-led learning and teaching. Famous for its excellent student social life in a unique
city.

[/imagecache/file/crop/200x200/media/1207539/3762_small.jpg] [/imagecache/file/crop/200x200/media/1207560/15786_small.jpg] [/imagecache/file/crop/200x200/media/1207574/8408.jpg] [/imagecache/file/crop/200x200/media/1207588/15474-1_small.jpg] 
ENTRY REQUIREMENTS
 * Sheffield's A level requirements range from AAA to ABB. Please refer to the university website for details.

TEACHING EXCELLENCE FRAMEWORK (TEF)
[/images/tef/Silver-100.jpg] TEF Silver is awarded to institutions that deliver high-quality teaching, learning and outcomes for
their students, and consistently exceed "rigorous national quality requirements" for higher education in the UK. Find out more
about TEF [/universities/choosing-the-right-university/teaching-excellence-framework-(tef)]. 

UNDERGRADUATE COURSES
TYPE OF QUALIFICATION:
 * Bachelor's Degree (256)
 * First Degree [/courses/search?i=The%20University%20of%20Sheffield&a=First%20Degree] (384)
 * LLB [/courses/search?i=The%20University%20of%20Sheffield&a=LLB] (7)
 * Master's Degree (128)
 * Other Undergraduate [/courses/search?i=The%20University%20of%20Sheffield&a=Other%20Undergraduate] (2)

MODE OF STUDY:
 * Full time [/courses/search?i=The%20University%20of%20Sheffield&m=Full%20time] (344)
 * Sandwich [/courses/search?i=The%20University%20of%20Sheffield&m=Sandwich] (42)

 Browse all undergraduate courses [/courses/search?i=The%20University%20of%20Sheffield]

COURSE FLEXIBILITY
 * The majority of courses offer the chance to study abroad for a semester or a year as part of the degree.
 * There is a strong emphasis on module choice and collaboration between departments with a wide range of dual degrees available.
 * Most courses allow students to tailor their degree to suit their own interests.
 * Some courses offer a year in industry, and some offer employment experience as part of the degree.

STUDENT SERVICES AND FACILITIES
 * Award-winning Information Commons centre with 500 PCs, wireless access throughout, open 24/7.
 * The university library contains 1.3 million books and journals, with access to a further 435,000 e-books and e-journals.
 * 1,609 computer workstations available for student use.
 * Free access to the Internet and email on campus, as well as off-campus access to files and email via the university portal.
 * The Diamond building includes specialist engineering teaching facilities, library services and social spaces, including a café.
 * The award-winning Student Services Information Desk (SSiD) is the first place to go for information, help, support and advice
   and is staffed by a friendly, professional, team who are trained to help deal with questions and concerns.

DISABILITY SERVICES
 * For students with a long-term condition or impairment that can affect the ability to study, the university can provide
   specialist support for the duration of their studies.
 * Please refer to the university website for details.

STUDENTS' UNION
 * The highly-rated Students' Union is run by students, for students, providing practical help and support along with
   entertainment.
 * With over 300 student clubs and societies.
 * Club nights and live music events all year round, along with bars, cafes, shops and a cinema.

AVAILABILITY OF PART-TIME WORK
 * The Careers Service runs Jobshop, a walk-in service based in the union, advertising vacancies for students.
 * The Students’ Union itself employs over 500 students every year.

CAREERS GUIDANCE
 * Right from the first year of a student's degree, the Careers Service can help them work out what they want to do and how to get
   there.
 * Specialist advisers show students what employers are looking for and how to market themselves – not just their skills and
   subject knowledge but also their personality and achievements outside the classroom.
 * The service also provide opportunities throughout the course to meet employers offering placements, jobs and work experience.

STUDENT MIX
STUDENT POPULATION
Small <5,000 Medium 5,000–10,000 Large >10,000 LEVEL OF STUDY
 * Undergraduate 70% 
 * Postgraduate 30% 

MODE OF STUDY
 * Full Time 90% 
 * Part Time 10% 

WHERE STUDENTS COME FROM
 * UK 69% 
 * EU 5% 
 * Other 26% 

STUDENT GENDER
 * Male 49% 
 * Female 51% 



HISTORY
 * Granted Royal Charter in 1905 and opened by King Edward VII.
 * Winner of four Queen's Anniversary Prizes in 1998, 2000, 2002 and 2007.
 * Former staff and alumni include six Nobel Prize winners.

NOTABLE ALUMNI
 * The Rt Hon David Blunkett – former MP for Sheffield Brightside.
 * Stephen Daldry CBE – director of films Billy Elliott, The Hours, and The Reader. Artistic Director of Royal Court Theatre
   (1992-1998)
 * Jessica Ennis – Olympic Heptathlon Champion, London 2012. European Heptathlon Champion, Barcelona 2010. World Heptathlon
   Champion, Berlin 2009.
 * Joanne Harris – award-winning author of books including Chocolat.
 * Eddie Izzard – comedian, actor.
 * Amy Johnson – pioneering aviator of the 1930s.
 * Sir Harry Kroto – Nobel Prize for Chemistry 1996.
 * Vanessa Lawrence CB – Director General of Ordnance Survey.
 * Hilary Mantel CBE, FRSL – author and winner of the Man Booker Prize 2009.
 * Helen Sharman OBE – Britain's first astronaut.

FURTHER DETAILS
Address The University of Sheffield Western Bank Sheffield S10 2TN UCAS Code S18 Content accurate at the time of compilation.
However, details may be subject to change. You should always confirm details with the provider.

Glyndŵr York York St John ABOUT THE SITE
Our independent UKUniversity League Tables & Rankings 2018 [/league-tables/rankings]give you a good guide to which university is
best for you, overall and by subject. We work closely with all mainUK Universities [/universities/], HESA and UCAS.

We help students around the world research degree courses, universities and colleges, accommodation, careers, and to make the
right choice in changing times.

WELCOME TO SHEFFIELD FC – THE WORLD’S FIRST FOOTBALL CLUB

In the year of 1857 William Prest and Nathaniel Creswick founded the first football club in the world.
Two pioneers, that developed new rules and laws for a game to play with friends of all ages in the community. Early both gentlemen
saw the power of football to connect people with grace, happiness
and respect for one another. Starting with the inventions of 1857, football became a strong social
and emotional basement for the citizens of Sheffield - and is today the world's greatest game.

Throughout history, our club Sheffield FC has always played football at amateur level. When the first
professional league was founded in 1885, the club wasn’t strong enough to compete with the newly formed and paid pro-teams and so
decided to set up the first official amateur competition in football.

Being proud of our status as true amateur club, we have developed a grass roots environment with
more than 12 teams – from an under 14 girls’ team to over 35 and Ex Sheffield Players – a place for
every football enthusiast, living within the region of Sheffield.

To preserve our heritage and the nature of football, our club has founded its own foundation in 2010. Therewith the club will
never invest in future players, but in different local and global projects to
spread the true values of the game: Integrity, Respect and Community.

On the following pages you will find more information to the topics mentioned above as well as to
further interesting content about the Club. And in case you want to get closer to football’s first club,
contact our chairman and come on over to visit us at the Home of Football, back in little Sheffield.

Yours in Football,
Sheffield FC

ABOUT OUR SHEFFIELD UNITED NEWS...
NewsNow aims to be the world's most accurate and comprehensive Sheffield United news aggregator, bringing you the latest Blades
headlines from the best Sheffield sites and other key national and regional sports sources. Breaking news from each site is
brought to you automatically and continuously 24/7, within around 10 minutes of publication. N.B. Relevance is automatically
assessed so some headlines not qualifying as Sheffield United news might appear - please feel free to contact us [/contact/] 
regarding any persistent issues. [Read more]  * My Most Viewed [javascript://]

Coordinates [/wiki/Geographic_coordinate_system]: 53°22′53″N 1°29′18″W/53.381389°N 1.488272°W/ 53.381389; -1.488272
[//tools.wmflabs.org/geohack/geohack.php?pagename=University_of_Sheffield&params=53.381389_N_1.488272_W_type:edu]CampusUrban
Colours [/wiki/School_colors]Black & goldAffiliationsRussell Group [/wiki/Russell_Group], WUN
[/wiki/Worldwide_Universities_Network], ACU [/wiki/Association_of_Commonwealth_Universities], N8 Group [/wiki/N8_Group], White

[//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/7/75/University_of_Sheffield_logo.png] [/wiki/File:University_of_Sheffield_logo.png]The University of Sheffield (informally Sheffield University[3][4]) is a public [/wiki/Public_university] research university
[/wiki/Research_university] in Sheffield [/wiki/Sheffield], South Yorkshire [/wiki/South_Yorkshire], England. It received its 
royal charter [/wiki/Royal_charter] in 1905 as successor to the University College of Sheffield, which was established in 1897 by
the merger of Sheffield Medical School [/wiki/Sheffield_Medical_School] (founded in 1828), Firth College (1879) and Sheffield
Technical School (1884).[5]

Sheffield is a multi-campus university predominantly over two campus areas: the Western Bank and the St George's.[6] The
university is organised into five academic faculties composed of multiple departments. It had 19,555 undergraduate and 8,370
postgraduate students in 2015/16. The annual income of the institution for 2016–17 was £623.6 million of which £155.9 million was
from research grants and contracts, with an expenditure of £633.0 million.[1] Sheffield ranks among the top 10 of UK universities
for research grant funding.[7]

Sheffield was placed 82nd worldwide according to QS World University Rankings [/wiki/QS_World_University_Rankings][8] and 104th
worldwide according to Times Higher Education World University Rankings [/wiki/Times_Higher_Education_World_University_Rankings].
[9] It was ranked 12th in the UK amongst multi-faculty institutions for the quality (GPA) of its research[10] and for its Research
Power in the 2014 Research Excellence Framework [/wiki/Research_Excellence_Framework].[11] In 2011, Sheffield was named
'University of the Year' in the Times Higher Education [/wiki/Times_Higher_Education] awards.[12] The Times Higher Education
Student Experience Survey 2014 ranked the University of Sheffield 1st for student experience, social life, university facilities
and accommodation, among other categories.[13]

It is one of the original red brick universities [/wiki/Red_brick_universities], a member of the Russell Group
[/wiki/Russell_Group] of research-intensive universities, the Worldwide Universities Network
[/wiki/Worldwide_Universities_Network], the N8 Group [/wiki/N8_Group] of the eight most research intensive universities in
Northern England and the White Rose University Consortium [/wiki/White_Rose_University_Consortium]. There are six Nobel laureates 
amongst Sheffield academics, alumni or former staff.[14]

HISTORY[EDIT [/W/INDEX.PHP?TITLE=UNIVERSITY_OF_SHEFFIELD&ACTION=EDIT&SECTION=1]]
ORIGINS[EDIT [/W/INDEX.PHP?TITLE=UNIVERSITY_OF_SHEFFIELD&ACTION=EDIT&SECTION=2]]
[//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/38/Mark_Firth_MC.jpg/150px-Mark_Firth_MC.jpg] [/wiki/File:Mark_Firth_MC.jpg] 
[/wiki/File:Mark_Firth_MC.jpg]Portrait of Mark Firth [/wiki/Mark_Firth], opened Firth College in 1879The University of Sheffield
was originally formed by the merger of three colleges. The Sheffield School of Medicine was founded in 1828, followed in 1879[15] 
by the opening of Firth College, which developed out of the Cambridge University Extension Movement scheme, by Mark Firth
[/wiki/Mark_Firth], a steel manufacturer, to teach arts [/wiki/Arts] and science subjects.[16] Firth College then helped to fund
the opening of the Sheffield Technical School in 1884 to teach applied science [/wiki/Applied_science], the only major faculty the
existing colleges did not cover. The Sheffield Technical School was founded because of local concern about the need for technical
training, particularly steelmaking in Sheffield, and the school moved to St George's Square in 1886.[16] The three institutions
merged in 1897 to form the University College of Sheffield by Royal Charter.[16] Sheffield was the only large city in England
without a University. Steelworkers, coal miners, factory workers and the people of Sheffield donated over £50,000 in 1904 to help
found the University of Sheffield.[17]

ROYAL CHARTER[EDIT [/W/INDEX.PHP?TITLE=UNIVERSITY_OF_SHEFFIELD&ACTION=EDIT&SECTION=3]]
[//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/71/Sheffieldunifundrasingposter.jpg/150px-Sheffieldunifundrasingposter.jpg]
[/wiki/File:Sheffieldunifundrasingposter.jpg] [/wiki/File:Sheffieldunifundrasingposter.jpg]The poster which helped raise funds for
the University (1904/1905)It was originally envisaged that the University College would join Manchester [/wiki/Victoria_University_of_Manchester], Liverpool
[/wiki/University_of_Liverpool] and Leeds [/wiki/University_of_Leeds] as the fourth member of the federal Victoria University
[/wiki/Victoria_University_(United_Kingdom)]. However, the Victoria University began to split up as independent universities
before this could happen and so the University College of Sheffield received its own Royal Charter [/wiki/Royal_Charter] on 31 May
1905 and became the University of Sheffield. In July 1905, Firth Court on Western Bank was opened by King Edward VII
[/wiki/King_Edward_VII] and Queen Alexandra [/wiki/Queen_Alexandra]. St George's Square remained the centre of departments of
Applied Science, and the departments of Arts, Medicine and Science moved to Western Bank.[16] Sheffield is one of the six red
brick universities [/wiki/Red_brick_universities], the civic universities founded in the major industrial cities of England.

DEVELOPMENT SINCE 1905[EDIT [/W/INDEX.PHP?TITLE=UNIVERSITY_OF_SHEFFIELD&ACTION=EDIT&SECTION=4]]
[//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/12/Sheffield_Uni.jpg/220px-Sheffield_Uni.jpg] [/wiki/File:Sheffield_Uni.jpg] 
[/wiki/File:Sheffield_Uni.jpg]Firth Court, opened in 1905, with the Royal CharterIn 1905, there were 114 full-time students, and
the first Hall of Residence (Stephenson Hall) and library (Edgar Allen library) had been established by then. The number of
students increased to a short-lived peak of 1,000 in 1919. During the First World War [/wiki/First_World_War], some of the
academic subjects and courses were replaced by teaching of munitions making and medical appliances production.[16] Rather than
from a single centre, the university has expanded since the 1920s from two ends, the Firth Court on Western Bank and the Sir
Frederick Mappin Building on the St George's site.[6]

In 1943, the University Grants Committee [/wiki/University_Grants_Committee_(UK)] announced that universities in the UK should
look forward to expansion in the years after the Second World War [/wiki/Second_World_War].[6] Sheffield predicted a 50% increase
in student population but the university was unprepared for such growth. There was pressure on the university to expand since the
student numbers had increased from around 1,000 to 3,000 by 1946.[6] The university announced proposals for development in 1947,
which emphasised the need for new departments, medical school, library, administration building, halls of residence, as well as
the completion of the Western Bank Quadrangles and the extension of the Students’ Union.[6]

The university then grew slowly until the 1950s and 1960s when it began to expand rapidly. Many new buildings (including the Main
Library and the Arts Tower [/wiki/Arts_Tower]) were built and older houses were brought into academic use. Student numbers
increased to their present levels of just under 26,000. At the same time in the 1950s, the university was expanding at other
sites, including the St Georges area.[6] From the 1960s, many more buildings have been constructed or extended, including the
Union of Students and St George's Library. The campus master plan proposed in the 1940s was completed by the 1970s, and the
university required a new development plan.[6]

[//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/81/Octagon_1.jpg/220px-Octagon_1.jpg] [/wiki/File:Octagon_1.jpg] 
[/wiki/File:Octagon_1.jpg]The Octagon Centre was opened in 1983 as a conference and music venueThe 1980s saw the opening of many
new buildings and centres, such as the multi-purpose Octagon Centre [/wiki/Octagon_Centre] and the Sir Henry Stephenson Building.
The university's teaching hospital, Northern General Hospital [/wiki/Northern_General_Hospital], was also extended.[6] In 1987 the
University began to collaborate with its once would-be partners of the Victoria University by co-founding the Northern Consortium
[/wiki/NCUK]; a coalition for the education and recruitment of international students.[16]

1990S ONWARDS[EDIT [/W/INDEX.PHP?TITLE=UNIVERSITY_OF_SHEFFIELD&ACTION=EDIT&SECTION=5]]
The university continued to expand in the 1990s. New premises were opened for School of the Clinical Dentistry, the Division of
Education, and the Management School.[6] In 1995, the University took over the Sheffield and North Trent College of Nursing and
Midwifery, the St George's Hospital was extended and a new building at the Northern General Hospital has been constructed, which
greatly increased the size of the medical faculty. In 2005, the South Yorkshire Strategic Health Authority announced that it would
split the training between Sheffield and Sheffield Hallam University [/wiki/Sheffield_Hallam_University] – however, the University
decided to pull out of providing preregistration nursing and midwifery training due to "costs and operational difficulties".[18]

In the 21st century, the University opened many more major buildings, such as the Jessop Building, the Soundhouse, Jessop West and
the Information Commons. The Arts Tower building, the Students' Union and University House buildings, the Sheffield Bioincubator
and University Health Centre were also refurbished.[16] A new six-storey building, the Diamond, was opened on 28 September 2015.
[19] In February 2016, the university started to work with Sheffield City Council [/wiki/Sheffield_City_Council] to transform
public spaces around the campus.[20] The £8 million project includes building and improving pedestrianisation
[/wiki/Pedestrianisation], crossings, cycle routes, as well as greening the campus.[20][21]

BUILDINGS AND LOCATIONS[EDIT [/W/INDEX.PHP?TITLE=UNIVERSITY_OF_SHEFFIELD&ACTION=EDIT&SECTION=6]]
[//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/81/Sheffield_Arts_Tower.png/220px-Sheffield_Arts_Tower.png]
[/wiki/File:Sheffield_Arts_Tower.png] [/wiki/File:Sheffield_Arts_Tower.png]The Arts Tower [/wiki/Arts_Tower] and Western Bank
Library[//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/06/Information_commons.jpg/220px-Information_commons.jpg]
[/wiki/File:Information_commons.jpg] [/wiki/File:Information_commons.jpg]The Information Commons
[/wiki/Information_Commons,_Sheffield]MAIN (WESTERN BANK) CAMPUS[EDIT [/W/INDEX.PHP?TITLE=UNIVERSITY_OF_SHEFFIELD&ACTION=EDIT&SECTION=7]]
The University of Sheffield is not a campus university [/wiki/Campus_university], though most of its buildings are located in
fairly close proximity to each other. The centre of the University's presence lies one mile to the west of Sheffield city centre,
where there is a mile-long collection of buildings belonging almost entirely to the University. This area includes the Sheffield
Students' Union [/wiki/University_of_Sheffield_Union_of_Students] (housed next door to University House
[/wiki/University_House,_University_of_Sheffield]), the Octagon Centre [/wiki/Octagon_Centre], Firth Court [/wiki/Firth_Court],
the Geography and Planning building, the Alfred Denny Building [/wiki/Alfred_Denny_Building] (housing natural sciences
[/wiki/Natural_sciences], the Departments of Animal and Plant Sciences and Biology, and including a small museum), the Dainton and
Richard Roberts Buildings and the Hicks Building [/wiki/Hicks_Building].

The Grade II*-listed [/wiki/Listed_building] library and Arts Tower [/wiki/Arts_Tower] are also located in this cluster.[22] A
concourse under the main road (the A57 [/wiki/A57_road]) allows students to easily move between these buildings.

Amongst the more recent additions to the universities estate are The Information Commons [/wiki/Information_Commons,_Sheffield],
opened in 2007, The Soundhouse (2008) and the Jessop West building (2009), the first UK project by renowned Berlin architects 
Sauerbruch Hutton [/wiki/Sauerbruch_Hutton].[23] In addition, throughout 2010 the Western Bank Library received a £3.3 million
restoration and refurbishment, the University of Sheffield Union of Students [/wiki/University_of_Sheffield_Union_of_Students] 
underwent a £5 million rebuild, and work commenced on a multimillion-pound refurbishment of the grade II* listed Arts Tower
[/wiki/Arts_Tower] to extend its lifespan by 30 years.[24]

THE OCTAGON CENTRE[EDIT [/W/INDEX.PHP?TITLE=UNIVERSITY_OF_SHEFFIELD&ACTION=EDIT&SECTION=8]]
Main article: Octagon Centre [/wiki/Octagon_Centre]The Octagon Centre is a multi-purpose conference centre and music venue
situated at the Western Bank campus, and is joined by a skyway to University House
[/wiki/University_House,_University_of_Sheffield]. The Octagon Centre comprises an eight-sided auditorium with a capacity of 1600,
offices, meeting rooms, and a lounge with bar and patio.[25] The Octagon Centre consists of a main auditorium known as the
Convocation Hall, with offices and meeting rooms in corridors across two floors at a lower elevation on the southern side of the
building, and a bar lounge. All of these areas are connected by a foyer entrance block. The building is connected to University
House by a footbridge, offering access to University House's catering facilities.

FIRTH COURT AND ALFRED DENNY BUILDING[EDIT [/W/INDEX.PHP?TITLE=UNIVERSITY_OF_SHEFFIELD&ACTION=EDIT&SECTION=9]]
[//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0e/Denny_Perak.jpg/220px-Denny_Perak.jpg] [/wiki/File:Denny_Perak.jpg] 
[/wiki/File:Denny_Perak.jpg]The Alfred Denny BuildingMain articles: Firth Court [/wiki/Firth_Court] and Alfred Denny Building
[/wiki/Alfred_Denny_Building]Firth Court is the main administrative centre for the University of Sheffield, stands at the heart of
the University precinct on Western Bank. It originally housed the Arts, Science and Medicine departments, while it is currently
home to the Department for Molecular Biology and Biotechnology and Biomedical Science. The building was opened by King Edward VII
and Queen Alexandra in 1905, and is named after Mark Firth [/wiki/Mark_Firth].[16]

The Rotunda, located to the left of Firth Court, is the Registrar and Secretary's Office.[26] It was formerly the Edgar Allen
Library, opened 26 April 1909 by Prince and Princess of Wales.[27]

Alfred Denny Building, a red brick building named after the first Professor of Zoology at the department, is linked to Firth Court
via the Addison Building. The building houses the Biomedical Science, Animal and Plant Science Departments including its
associated museum, Disability and Dyslexia Support Service, and the Perak Laboratories.[28]

DAINTON AND RICHARD ROBERTS BUILDINGS[EDIT [/W/INDEX.PHP?TITLE=UNIVERSITY_OF_SHEFFIELD&ACTION=EDIT&SECTION=10]]
[//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/University_of_Sheffield%2C_Chemistry_Department_-_geograph.org.uk_-_2891461.jpg/220px-University_of_Sheffield%2C_Chemistry_Department_-_geograph.org.uk_-_2891461.jpg]
[/wiki/File:University_of_Sheffield,_Chemistry_Department_-_geograph.org.uk_-_2891461.jpg] 
[/wiki/File:University_of_Sheffield,_Chemistry_Department_-_geograph.org.uk_-_2891461.jpg]Dainton and Richard Roberts Buildings in
1971The Dainton Building, houses the Department of Chemistry and Faculty of Sciences, is named after Sheffield academic chemist
and university chancellor Frederick Sydney Dainton [/wiki/Frederick_Sydney_Dainton]. The East Wing of Dainton Building was renamed
Richard Roberts Building after Nobel Laureate and University graduate Richard Roberts [/wiki/Richard_J._Roberts].

HICKS BUILDING[EDIT [/W/INDEX.PHP?TITLE=UNIVERSITY_OF_SHEFFIELD&ACTION=EDIT&SECTION=11]]
Main article: Hicks Building [/wiki/Hicks_Building]The Hicks Building is a building named after William Mitchinson Hicks [/wiki/William_Mitchinson_Hicks], a British mathematician
and physicist who spent most of his career at Sheffield, contributing to the development of the university. It houses the
departments of Physics and Astronomy, the Chemistry and Physics Workshop and the School of Mathematics and Statistics. The
Building is in three sections, including a taller building clad in red-brick, a shorter fully linked section clad in blue tiles
and glass, and a section facing the University Concourse.

ARTS TOWER AND WESTERN BANK LIBRARY[EDIT [/W/INDEX.PHP?TITLE=UNIVERSITY_OF_SHEFFIELD&ACTION=EDIT&SECTION=12]]
Main article: Arts Tower [/wiki/Arts_Tower]The Arts Tower is a Grade II* listed building [/wiki/Grade_II*_listed_building] opened in 1966.[5] It was the tallest in Sheffield
from 1965 to 2010, and is the tallest university building in the UK.[29] The building, previously housed several academic
departments, is now mainly an administration block. The Arts Tower houses one of Europe's few surviving examples of a Paternoster
[/wiki/Paternoster] lift.[30] A bridge at the mezzanine level links the tower to Western Bank Library. The two buildings are
intended to be viewed together.[31] Formerly known as the University Library, the Western Bank Library was the main library of the
University of Sheffield until the Information Commons [/wiki/Information_Commons] was established. The Grade II*-listed library is
home to 25,000 rare books and 150 special collections.[32]

ST GEORGE'S[EDIT [/W/INDEX.PHP?TITLE=UNIVERSITY_OF_SHEFFIELD&ACTION=EDIT&SECTION=13]]
To the east lies St George's Campus, named after St George's Church [/wiki/St_George%27s_Church,_Portobello] (now a lecture
theatre and postgraduate residence). The campus is centred on Mappin Street, home to a number of University buildings, including
the Faculty of Engineering (partly housed in the Grade II-listed [/wiki/Listed_building] Mappin Building [/wiki/Mappin_Building])
and the University of Sheffield School of Management and Department of computer science [/wiki/Computer_science]. The University
also maintains the Turner Museum of Glass [/wiki/Turner_Museum_of_Glass] in this area. The University recently converted the
listed old Victorian [/wiki/Victorian_architecture] Jessop Hospital for Women [/wiki/Jessop_Hospital] buildings into the new home
of the Department of Music. The adjacent Edwardian buildings and a large vacant plot of land opposite St George's Church
[/wiki/St_George%27s_Church,_Portobello] are awaiting development as and when funding permits.

The formerly grade II listed Edwardian wing of the Jessop Hospital was replaced by a new £81 million building for the Faculty of
Engineering which opened in September 2015, named The Diamond. It houses lecture theatres, laboratories, workrooms and other
facilities for the teaching of engineering, .[33][34]

SIR FREDERICK MAPPIN BUILDING[EDIT [/W/INDEX.PHP?TITLE=UNIVERSITY_OF_SHEFFIELD&ACTION=EDIT&SECTION=14]]
[//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/28/F_C_Mappin_2730.jpg/161px-F_C_Mappin_2730.jpg]
[/wiki/File:F_C_Mappin_2730.jpg]Sir Frederick Mappin [/wiki/Sir_Frederick_Mappin,_1st_Baronet]
[//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b1/Mappin2009.jpg/213px-Mappin2009.jpg] [/wiki/File:Mappin2009.jpg]Sir Frederick
Mappin Building, Faculty of EngineeringMain article: Sir Frederick Mappin Building [/wiki/Sir_Frederick_Mappin_Building]The Sir
Frederick Mappin Building is a grade II-listed building in an area known as the St George's Complex. The building houses much of
the Faculty of Engineering and St George's IT centre.[29] The oldest part of the building, the former Technical School, now lies
in the centre of the building. The extensive Mappin Street frontage includes the main entrance, the John Carr Library and Mappin
Hall, and is connected to the Technical School by a bridge.

ST GEORGE'S CHURCH[EDIT [/W/INDEX.PHP?TITLE=UNIVERSITY_OF_SHEFFIELD&ACTION=EDIT&SECTION=15]]
[//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/Stgeorges.jpg/220px-Stgeorges.jpg] [/wiki/File:Stgeorges.jpg] 
[/wiki/File:Stgeorges.jpg]St George's Church [/wiki/St_George%27s_Church,_Portobello]Main article: St George's Church, Portobello
[/wiki/St_George%27s_Church,_Portobello]St George's Church is a building built in the Perpendicular style. It was the first of
three commissioners' churches to be built in Sheffield under the Church Building Act 1818. The church closed in 1981 and was
acquired by the University. It was converted for use as a lecture theatre in 1994.[35]

WEST OF THE MAIN CAMPUS[EDIT [/W/INDEX.PHP?TITLE=UNIVERSITY_OF_SHEFFIELD&ACTION=EDIT&SECTION=16]]
Further west lies Weston Park, the Weston Park Museum [/wiki/Weston_Park_Museum], the Harold Cantor Gallery
[/wiki/Harold_Cantor_Gallery], sports facilities [/wiki/Goodwin_Sports_Centre] in the Crookesmoor [/wiki/Crookesmoor] area, and
the Faculty of Medicine, Dentistry and Health around the Royal Hallamshire Hospital [/wiki/Royal_Hallamshire_Hospital] (although
these subjects are taught in the city's extensive teaching hospitals [/wiki/Teaching_hospital] under the Sheffield Teaching
Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust [/wiki/Sheffield_Teaching_Hospitals_NHS_Foundation_Trust], and throughout South Yorkshire
[/wiki/South_Yorkshire] and North East Lincolnshire [/wiki/North_East_Lincolnshire]). It is in this area that the new £12 million
Sheffield Institute for Translational Neuroscience [/wiki/Neuroscience] (SITraN), opened by Her Majesty Queen Elizabeth II
[/wiki/Queen_Elizabeth_II] in November 2010, is located.[36]

LIBRARIES AND MUSEUMS[EDIT [/W/INDEX.PHP?TITLE=UNIVERSITY_OF_SHEFFIELD&ACTION=EDIT&SECTION=17]]
The University has currently five libraries, they are: the Information Commons [/wiki/Information_Commons,_Sheffield], Western
Bank Library, Health Sciences Libraries (Royal Hallamshire Hospital and Northern General Hospital), and The Diamond.[37] The
University of Sheffield Library is a member of Research Libraries UK [/wiki/Research_Libraries_UK].[38]

The Western Bank Library has an Exhibition Gallery.[39] The Gallery space enables collections from the University Library and the
National Fairground Archive to be displayed in controlled conditions.[40]

The Alfred Denny Museum is a museum operated by the University.[41] It was established in 1905, and was located in Firth Court
then moved to Alfred Denny Building.[42] The Museum has specimens from all major phyla, and two letters written from Charles
Darwin to Henry Denny. Many of the specimens have been collected since the 1900s, but much of the information about the collection
was lost during the Second World War.[43]

The Turner Museum of Glass [/wiki/Turner_Museum_of_Glass] houses the University's collections of 19th and 20th century glass.[44] 
It contains mainly from major European and American glassworkers and examples from ancient Egypt and Rome. It is in the Hadfield
Building. It was founded by W E S Turner[44][45] of the University in 1943. One of the exhibits is the wedding dress of Helen
Nairn (Turner's wife) which is made of glass fibre. This has been selected as one of the items in the BBC's A History of the World
in 100 Objects.[46]

The Traditional Heritage Museum (THM) was part of the National Centre for English Cultural Tradition opened to the public in 1985.
[47] It was created by Prof Widdowson in 1964 and was run by volunteers and students.[48] The THM housed collections including a
replica kitchen from the 1920s, reconstructed workshops and retail shops, such as Pollard’s tea and coffee.[47] The University
decided to close the Museum in 2011 because the building could not afford continued public access.[47][49]

MANVERS CAMPUS[EDIT [/W/INDEX.PHP?TITLE=UNIVERSITY_OF_SHEFFIELD&ACTION=EDIT&SECTION=18]]
The Manvers [/wiki/Manvers] campus, at Wath-on-Dearne [/wiki/Wath-on-Dearne] between Rotherham [/wiki/Rotherham] and Barnsley
[/wiki/Barnsley], was where the majority of nursing was taught, but this has now been mothballed.

ORGANISATION[EDIT [/W/INDEX.PHP?TITLE=UNIVERSITY_OF_SHEFFIELD&ACTION=EDIT&SECTION=20]]

SCHOOL OF ARCHITECTURE[EDIT [/W/INDEX.PHP?TITLE=UNIVERSITY_OF_SHEFFIELD&ACTION=EDIT&SECTION=22]]
The Sheffield School of Architecture [/wiki/Sheffield_School_of_Architecture] is one of the longest established architecture
schools in the UK, opening in 1908, and was located in the tower of Firth Court. It was soon moved to the Sunday School in
Shearwood Road and is located on the top 6 floors of the Arts Tower since 1965.[51]

The School has courses accredited by the Architects Registration Board (ARB) and the Royal Institute of British Architects (RIBA),
and has an active student society (SUAS). In the Research Excellence Framework (REF) 2014, Sheffield School of Architecture ranked
4th in the UK.[52]

MANAGEMENT SCHOOL[EDIT [/W/INDEX.PHP?TITLE=UNIVERSITY_OF_SHEFFIELD&ACTION=EDIT&SECTION=23]]
Established in 1986, Sheffield University Management School [/wiki/University_of_Sheffield_Management_School] is an AMBA, AACSB
and EQUIS accredited business school. It is one of 60 business schools in the world to have achieved triple accreditation.[53]

In 2013 the school moved into newly refurbished facilities close to the University of Sheffield campus and Broomhill. It now has
dedicated learning and teaching space, a courtyard, dedicated café and Employability Hub.[54]

MEDICAL SCHOOL[EDIT [/W/INDEX.PHP?TITLE=UNIVERSITY_OF_SHEFFIELD&ACTION=EDIT&SECTION=24]]
Sheffield Medical School [/wiki/Sheffield_Medical_School] was founded in 1828. It operated independently as the Sheffield School
of Medicine until its mergers with Firth College in 1879 and with Sheffield Technical School in 1884.[55]

The Medical School is one of 32 bodies entitled by the General Medical Council (GMC) to award medical degrees in the United
Kingdom. The GMC is the body responsible for registering doctors to practise medicine as well as regulating medical education and
training in the United Kingdom.[56]

GOVERNANCE[EDIT [/W/INDEX.PHP?TITLE=UNIVERSITY_OF_SHEFFIELD&ACTION=EDIT&SECTION=25]]
There are several bodies which govern the University, including the University Executive Board, the Court, the Council and the
Senate.

The University Executive Board, whose members are: Vice-Chancellor, five Faculty Pro-Vice-Chancellors, two Institutional
Pro-Vice-Chancellors (Research and Innovation, and Learning and Teaching), Registrar and Secretary, chief financial officer (CFO),
and Director of Human Resources.

The Court is a large body which fosters relations between the University and the community, and includes lay members, many of whom
are University alumni. Ex-officio [/wiki/Ex-officio] members of the Court include all the MPs [/wiki/Member_of_Parliament] of
Sheffield, the Bishops of Sheffield and Hallam, and the Chief Constable of South Yorkshire Police.[57] It also includes
representatives of professional bodies such as the Arts Council [/wiki/Arts_Council_of_England], Royal Society
[/wiki/Royal_Society] and the General Medical Council [/wiki/General_Medical_Council].[58] Court meets annually to receive reports
from the Council, the Senate and the Students' Union. It serves many official functions including Chancellor election.

The Council manages the University's business side (finance and property).[57] Council membership comprises a majority of
non-executive lay members. The chair and deputy chair hold the title Pro-Chancellor and currently are Tony Pedder and Sarah
Harkness.[59] The Senate manages the academic side of the University. It is the highest academic authority of the University, and
is chaired by the Vice-Chancellor. It is also responsible for the regulation of the students' discipline.[57]

VICE-CHANCELLORS[EDIT [/W/INDEX.PHP?TITLE=UNIVERSITY_OF_SHEFFIELD&ACTION=EDIT&SECTION=26]]
 * 1905: Charles Eliot [/wiki/Charles_Eliot_(diplomat)]

FINANCES[EDIT [/W/INDEX.PHP?TITLE=UNIVERSITY_OF_SHEFFIELD&ACTION=EDIT&SECTION=27]]
The university's annual income for 2014–15 was £560.6 million of which £144.1 million was from research grants and contracts, with
an expenditure of £539.3 million resulting in a surplus of £21.3 million. Its endowment was £39.0 million.[60]

COAT OF ARMS[EDIT [/W/INDEX.PHP?TITLE=UNIVERSITY_OF_SHEFFIELD&ACTION=EDIT&SECTION=28]]
[//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cf/ShefuniCourtofarms2012.JPG/170px-ShefuniCourtofarms2012.JPG]
[/wiki/File:ShefuniCourtofarms2012.JPG] [/wiki/File:ShefuniCourtofarms2012.JPG]The University Coat of Arms, displayed on the front
of Mappin BuildingThe arms of the University blazoned Azure, A gold-edged book inscribed with the Latin Disce Doce (Learn and Teach), A sheaf of
eight silver arrows on either side (from the arms of the city), The Crown of Success and The White Rose of York
[/wiki/White_Rose_of_York], with a scroll carrying the motto Rerum cognoscere causas (To Discover the Causes of Things; from
Virgil's Georgics II, 490), which was also the motto of Firth College.[61] The University's logo, consists of a redrawn version of
the Coat of Arms and the name of the institution, is introduced in 2005, the centenary year of the University. However, the Coat
of Arms remains the official heraldic symbol of the University, and should not be confused with the logo.[61]

BRANDING[EDIT [/W/INDEX.PHP?TITLE=UNIVERSITY_OF_SHEFFIELD&ACTION=EDIT&SECTION=29]]
[//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/4/44/University_of_Sheffield_coat_of_arms.png/84px-University_of_Sheffield_coat_of_arms.png]
[/wiki/File:University_of_Sheffield_coat_of_arms.png]Coat of arms
[//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/7/75/University_of_Sheffield_logo.png/249px-University_of_Sheffield_logo.png]
[/wiki/File:University_of_Sheffield_logo.png]The University' s logoThe brand (encompassing the visual identity) is centred on the
theme of "discovery", led by the Latin motto from the coat of arms "Rerum Cognoscere Causas" – "to discover the causes of things".
It has been applied across print, screen and other areas such as signage, vehicle livery and merchandising. The project was key to
the University's Marketing Department receiving "HEIST Marketing Team of the Year, 2005".[62]

The University's fonts are Stephenson and Blake. Both serif font Stephenson and sans serif font Blake are modified versions of a
typeface designed by Sheffield company Stephenson & Blake Co.[63][64]

ACADEMIC PROFILE[EDIT [/W/INDEX.PHP?TITLE=UNIVERSITY_OF_SHEFFIELD&ACTION=EDIT&SECTION=30]]
REPUTATION AND RANKINGS[EDIT [/W/INDEX.PHP?TITLE=UNIVERSITY_OF_SHEFFIELD&ACTION=EDIT&SECTION=31]]
Rankings [/wiki/College_and_university_rankings]ARWU [/wiki/Academic_Ranking_of_World_Universities][65]
(2017, national)10–17ARWU [/wiki/Academic_Ranking_of_World_Universities][66]
(2017, world)101–150QS [/wiki/QS_World_University_Rankings][67]
(2018, national)13QS [/wiki/QS_World_University_Rankings][68]
(2018, world)82THE [/wiki/Times_Higher_Education_World_University_Rankings][69]
(2018, national)13THE [/wiki/Times_Higher_Education_World_University_Rankings][70]
(2018, world)104CWTS Leiden [/wiki/CWTS_Leiden_Ranking][71]
(2017, world)131Complete[72]
(2018, national)31The Guardian[73]
(2018, national)40=Times/Sunday Times[74]
(2018, national)21Teaching Excellence Framework [/wiki/Teaching_Excellence_Framework][75]SilverThe university has been described
by The Times [/wiki/The_Times] as one of the powerhouses of British higher education,[76] and it was also constantly rated as a
world top-100 university by various league tables during the last decade.[77][78][79] The University is a member of the Russell
Group [/wiki/Russell_Group], the European University Association [/wiki/European_University_Association], the Worldwide
Universities Network [/wiki/Worldwide_Universities_Network] and the White Rose University Consortium
[/wiki/White_Rose_University_Consortium].[80][81][82]According to the analysis of research council data in 2016-17, the University
of Sheffield has been ranked 10th highest-earning institution for research grant funding in the UK.[83]

The QS World University Rankings [/wiki/QS_World_University_Rankings] 2015-16 and the THE World University Rankings 2015 placed
Sheffield 80th and 97th respectively in the world.[84]

Sheffield has won Queen's Anniversary Prizes [/wiki/Queen%27s_Anniversary_Prize] in 1998, 2000, 2002 and 2007.[85] In 2011 it was
named 'University of the Year' in the Times Higher Education [/wiki/Times_Higher_Education] awards.[12] The latest Times Higher
Education Student Experience Survey 2014 ranked the University of Sheffield 1st for student experience, social life, university
facilities and accommodation, among other categories.

In the 2014 Research Excellence Framework (REF) Sheffield was ranked 12th for research power [86] and 14th by GPA for research
quality in the UK,[87] with 86% (8th highest among the Russell Group) of the research submitted by the academic staff having been
rigorously judged as world leading (4*) or internationally excellent (3*).[88] The University was one of only eleven in the
country to make 30 or more submissions in a wide range of subject areas. Of the 35 submissions from Sheffield, 23 were judged to
be in the top ten in the Russell Group for the quality of their research outputs.The university is also in the UK's 9-15 bracket
of universities according to the Shanghai Jiao Tong University's ranking of the top 500 universities worldwide.[89]

The university's business school [/wiki/University_of_Sheffield_Management_School] is one of only five Russell Group business
schools to have the internationally recognised Triple Crown accreditation.[90] and social science at Sheffield is ranked 63rd
internationally and 12th in the UK by the Times Higher Education World University Rankings 2018.[91] The University of Sheffield
has the second highest research income in the UK for engineering and 93% of the research from its Faculty of Engineering was rated
as 'world leading' or 'internationally excellent' in REF 2014.[92] The University also came to 84th in the world and 8th in the UK
for engineering and technology according to the most recent league table.[93] In particular, its Advanced Manufacturing Research
Centre is a partnership with 100 companies including Boeing, involved in research into advanced manufacturing technologies used in
the aerospace, automotive, medical and other high-value manufacturing sectors.[94] Besides, the university is ranked 95th globally
for clinical, health and life sciences.[95]In addition to the strong tradition of excellence in engineering, medicine and science,
the Faculty of Arts and Humanities at Sheffield is also one of the best among its kind and ranked 67th in the world.[96]

ADMISSIONS[EDIT [/W/INDEX.PHP?TITLE=UNIVERSITY_OF_SHEFFIELD&ACTION=EDIT&SECTION=32]]

[/wiki/File:Firth_court_Sheffield.jpg] [/wiki/File:Firth_court_Sheffield.jpg]Firth Court QuadIn terms of average UCAS [/wiki/UCAS] points of entrants, Sheffield ranked 29th in Britain in 2014.[100] The university gives
offers of admission to 85.6% of its applicants, the 4th highest amongst the Russell Group [/wiki/Russell_Group].[101]

According to the 2017 Times and Sunday Times Good University Guide, approximately 13% of Sheffield's undergraduates come from
independent schools.[102] In the 2016-17 academic year, the university had a domicile breakdown of 71:5:24 of UK:EU:non-EU
students respectively with a female to male ratio of 51:49.[103]

RESEARCH PARTNERS[EDIT [/W/INDEX.PHP?TITLE=UNIVERSITY_OF_SHEFFIELD&ACTION=EDIT&SECTION=33]]
Major research partners and clients include Boeing [/wiki/Boeing], Rolls Royce [/wiki/Rolls-Royce_plc], Siemens, Unilever
[/wiki/Unilever], Boots [/wiki/Alliance_Boots], AstraZeneca [/wiki/AstraZeneca], GSK [/wiki/GlaxoSmithKline], ICI
[/wiki/Imperial_Chemical_Industries], and Slazenger [/wiki/Slazenger], as well as UK and overseas government agencies and
charitable foundations.[104]

The university also works with local small and medium enterprises [/wiki/Small_and_medium_enterprises] through the dedicated
physical spaces at the Sheffield Bioincubator [/wiki/Sheffield_Bioincubator] and Kroto Innovation Centre
[/wiki/Kroto_Innovation_Centre].[105][106]

For many years the University has been engaged in theological publishing through Sheffield Academic Press
[/wiki/Sheffield_Academic_Press] and JSOT [/wiki/JSOT] Press.

The university is a partner organisation in Higher Futures [/wiki/Higher_Futures], a collaborative association of institutions set
up under the government's Lifelong Learning Networks [/wiki/Lifelong_Learning_Networks] initiative, to co-ordinate vocational and
work-based education.[107]

As well as the research carried out in departments, the university has over 180 specialised research centres or institutes.[108] 
The last Teaching Quality Assessment awarded Sheffield University grades of "excellent" in 29 subject areas, a record equalled by
only a few other UK universities.[109]

INVOLVEMENT WITH THE ARMS TRADE[EDIT [/W/INDEX.PHP?TITLE=UNIVERSITY_OF_SHEFFIELD&ACTION=EDIT&SECTION=34]]
The University of Sheffield's Advanced Manufacturing Research Centre is run in partnership with Boeing, which conducts research
projects funded by arms manufacturers such as BAE Systems.[110] In 2008, the University partnered with BAE Systems to launch a new
Centre for Research in Active Control which aimed to improve the stealth of BAE Systems' submarines.[111] In 2012 the Students
Union voted in favour of the University ending all links with the arms trade.[112]

STUDENT LIFE[EDIT [/W/INDEX.PHP?TITLE=UNIVERSITY_OF_SHEFFIELD&ACTION=EDIT&SECTION=35]]
[//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/Shefunistudentunion2012.JPG/220px-Shefunistudentunion2012.JPG]
[/wiki/File:Shefunistudentunion2012.JPG] [/wiki/File:Shefunistudentunion2012.JPG]Students' Union
[/wiki/University_of_Sheffield_Students%27_Union]STUDENTS' UNION[EDIT [/W/INDEX.PHP?TITLE=UNIVERSITY_OF_SHEFFIELD&ACTION=EDIT&SECTION=36]]
Main article: University of Sheffield Students' Union [/wiki/University_of_Sheffield_Students%27_Union]The University of Sheffield Students' Union [/wiki/University_of_Sheffield_Students%27_Union] was founded in 1906 and has nearly
three hundred student societies and nearly fifty sports teams. Sheffield University Football Club
[/wiki/Sheffield_University_F.C.] has been established for many decades and has previously competed in the FA Amateur Cup
[/wiki/FA_Amateur_Cup] and FA Vase [/wiki/FA_Vase]. The Union building contains society and union workplaces and coffee shops,
restaurants, shops, and the student run cinema Film Unit [/wiki/Film_Unit]. Facilities include two bars (Bar One – which has a
book-able function room with its own bar, The Raynor Lounge – and The Interval); a three room club venue (Foundry); There is also
a student radio [/wiki/Student_radio] station called Forge Radio [/wiki/Forge_Radio] and a newspaper called Forge Press, which are
run under the umbrella of 'Forge Media'.

In November 2009 a development project began to redevelop the Students' Union building, funded by £5 million by the HEFCE, which
was completed and re-opened in September 2010. Works centred on improving circulation around the building by aligning previously
disjointed floors, improving internal access between the Union building and neighbouring University House, and constructing a new
entrance and lobby that incorporates the university's traditional colours of black and gold. During 2012–13 the Students' Union
went under a further redevelopment costing £20 million which led to the refurbishment of the University House. University House,
which was one of the first glass curtain walled buildings in the world when it was completed in 1963, has now been integrated with
the University's Students' Union in one single building.[113]

STUDENT ACCOMMODATION[EDIT [/W/INDEX.PHP?TITLE=UNIVERSITY_OF_SHEFFIELD&ACTION=EDIT&SECTION=37]]
The University halls of residence [/wiki/Halls_of_residence] comprises two separate sites: Ranmoor/Endcliffe, and City.[114]

Off campus can be found Sheffield Student Housing Co-operative [/wiki/Sheffield_Student_Housing_Co-operative], a student housing
cooperative [/wiki/Student_housing_cooperative] providing not-for-profit, student-managed housing for its members. They currently
manage a property on Northfield Road in Crookes, Sheffield.

VARSITY SPORTS[EDIT [/W/INDEX.PHP?TITLE=UNIVERSITY_OF_SHEFFIELD&ACTION=EDIT&SECTION=38]]
The annual Sheffield Varsity takes place between teams from the University and its rival Sheffield Hallam University
[/wiki/Sheffield_Hallam_University] starting from 1996.[115] Varsity is divided into winter and summer competitions.[115] The
University has 26 varsity sports (sports contested in varsity). The University sports colours are black and gold. The University
of Sheffield won the Varsity competition in 2013, beating Sheffield Hallam University for the first time in ten years.[116] It
extended the new found winning streak to five years in a row; winning again in 2014, 2015, 2016 and 2017.[117][118]

NOBEL PRIZES[EDIT [/W/INDEX.PHP?TITLE=UNIVERSITY_OF_SHEFFIELD&ACTION=EDIT&SECTION=41]]
The University's Faculty of Science is associated with six Nobel laureates
[/wiki/List_of_Nobel_laureates_by_university_affiliation], two for the Department of Molecular Biology [/wiki/Molecular_Biology] 
and Biotechnology [/wiki/Biotechnology]:

 * 1945 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine [/wiki/Nobel_Prize_in_Physiology_or_Medicine] (joint award) Howard Florey
   [/wiki/Howard_Florey], for his work on penicillin[119]
 * 1953 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine, Hans Adolf Krebs [/wiki/Hans_Adolf_Krebs], "for the discovery of the citric acid
   cycle [/wiki/Citric_acid_cycle] in cellular respiration [/wiki/Cellular_respiration]"[120]

And four to its Department of Chemistry:

 * 1967 Nobel Prize in Chemistry (joint award), George Porter [/wiki/George_Porter], "for their work on extremely fast chemical
   reactions" (see Flash photolysis [/wiki/Flash_photolysis])[121]
 * 1993 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine (joint award), Richard J. Roberts [/wiki/Richard_J._Roberts], "for the discovery
   that genes in eukaryotes are not contiguous strings but contain introns, and that the splicing of messenger RNA to delete those
   introns can occur in different ways, yielding different proteins from the same DNA sequence"[122]
 * 1996 Nobel Prize in Chemistry (joint award), Sir Harry Kroto [/wiki/Harry_Kroto], "for their discovery of fullerenes"[123]
 * 2016 Nobel Prize in Chemistry (joint award), Sir James Fraser Stoddart [/wiki/Fraser_Stoddart], "for the design and synthesis
   of molecular machines"[124]

 * [//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d2/Howard_Walter_Florey_1945.jpg/85px-Howard_Walter_Florey_1945.jpg]
   [/wiki/File:Howard_Walter_Florey_1945.jpg]Howard Florey [/wiki/Howard_Florey]
 * [//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/ba/Hans_Adolf_Krebs.jpg/85px-Hans_Adolf_Krebs.jpg]
   [/wiki/File:Hans_Adolf_Krebs.jpg]Hans Adolf Krebs [/wiki/Hans_Adolf_Krebs]
 * [//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/George_Porter_Nobel.jpg/85px-George_Porter_Nobel.jpg]
   [/wiki/File:George_Porter_Nobel.jpg]George Porter [/wiki/George_Porter]
 * [//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/19/Roberts%2C_Richard_John_%281943%29.jpg/89px-Roberts%2C_Richard_John_%281943%29.jpg]
   [/wiki/File:Roberts,_Richard_John_(1943).jpg]Richard Roberts [/wiki/Richard_J._Roberts]
 * [//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/69/Harold_Kroto_1c389_8471.sweden.jpg/80px-Harold_Kroto_1c389_8471.sweden.jpg]
   [/wiki/File:Harold_Kroto_1c389_8471.sweden.jpg]Harold Kroto [/wiki/Harold_Kroto]
 * [//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/24/Nobel_Laureates_0953_%2831117136180%29.jpg/96px-Nobel_Laureates_0953_%2831117136180%29.jpg]
   [/wiki/File:Nobel_Laureates_0953_(31117136180).jpg]Sir James Fraser Stoddart [/wiki/Fraser_Stoddart]

FURTHER READING[EDIT [/W/INDEX.PHP?TITLE=UNIVERSITY_OF_SHEFFIELD&ACTION=EDIT&SECTION=44]]
There are two official histories of the university:

 * Arthur W. Chapman (1955) The Story of a Modern University: A History of the University of Sheffield, Oxford University Press.
 * Helen Mathers (2005) Steel City Scholars: The Centenary History of the University of Sheffield, London: James & James.

YOU ARE HERE
 1. Local Police [/local-police]

SHEFFIELD 
Welcome to the Sheffield Neighbourhood Policing Team page.You can phone 101 to contact your Neighbourhood Policing Team or click
the map below to visit your team’s site where you will find information about your named officers, local priorities and further
contact details.

If you’re not sure when else to call 101, our help and advice page [http://www.southyorks.police.uk/node/20251] will guide you in
the right direction. You should always dial 999 if it’s an emergency.

Important information and crime prevention advice

Supporting victims of crime [http://www.southyorks.police.uk/sites/default/files/Victim%20leaflet%202011.pdf]

Burglary crime prevention advice [http://www.southyorks.police.uk/landing-page/homesafety]

Vehicle crime prevention advice [http://www.southyorks.police.uk/content/vehicle-crime]

Violent crime prevention advice [http://www.southyorks.police.uk/content/personal-safety-0]

Learn more about Sheffield District Commander Chief Superintendent David Hartley
[http://www.southyorks.police.uk/about-us/our-people/district-commanders/sheffield-district-commander]

Like or follow your Neighbourhood Policing Team on social media - click the links on the map below. You don't need a Facebook or
Twitter account to view the updates.[//cdn.thinglink.me/api/image/705028536183816194/1024/10/scaletowidth#tl-705028536183816194;1043138249']

[/sites/default/files/101-MPU-SYP-orange_2014%20%283%29_0.gif]
